LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
We waited for her down the road and out of sight. The minutes passed, slow and heavy, as the sun began to dip behind the trees, casting long shadows across the gravel. Tom stood a little apart from us, his hands thrust deep into his pockets, his jaw set in a hard line. Gatsby, on the other hand, seemed unable to stand still; he shifted his weight from foot to foot, his eyes fixed on the bend in the road where Daisy would appear. I could feel the tension radiating from him, a mixture of hope and dread that seemed to vibrate in the air between us.

At last, we heard the distant hum of an engine, and a moment later, Daisy’s car came into view, gliding toward us with a kind of nervous energy. She pulled up beside us, her face pale and drawn, her hands gripping the wheel so tightly that her knuckles were white. For a moment, no one spoke. The silence was thick, oppressive, broken only by the ticking of the engine as it cooled.

Gatsby stepped forward, his voice gentle. “Are you all right, Daisy?”

She nodded, but her eyes darted from Gatsby to Tom and back again, as if searching for some sign, some reassurance. Tom moved to her side, his expression softening as he looked at her. “Let’s go home,” he said quietly.

We climbed into the car, the four of us crowded together in the close confines of the vehicle. The drive back was silent, each of us lost in our own thoughts. The events of the afternoon hung over us like a cloud, heavy and suffocating. I glanced at Gatsby, who sat beside me, his gaze fixed on Daisy, his face etched with longing and fear.

As we approached the Buchanan house, the lights were already on, spilling golden pools onto the lawn. Tom helped Daisy out of the car, his hand lingering on her arm. Gatsby hesitated, standing a few steps behind, uncertain.

I followed them inside, the air cool and still. Daisy disappeared upstairs, and Tom turned to Gatsby, his voice low and controlled. “You’d better go. This isn’t your place.”

Gatsby looked at me, his eyes pleading. “I just want to make sure she’s safe.”

I nodded, understanding. “I’ll stay with her for a while. You go on.”

Reluctantly, Gatsby turned and walked out into the night, his figure silhouetted against the glow of the porch light. I watched him go, a sense of foreboding settling over me. Inside, the house was quiet, the only sound the distant murmur of Daisy’s voice as she spoke to Tom behind closed doors.

I stood in the hallway, uncertain, the weight of the evening pressing down on me. Outside, the world seemed to hold its breath, waiting for what would come next.

events.title: Arrival at the Manhattan Apartment
detailed_summary: They drive up Fifth Avenue on a warm Sunday afternoon.
The narrator attempts to leave, but Tom insists he must come up to the apartment to avoid offending Myrtle.
Myrtle encourages him, promising to call her sister Catherine, described as beautiful.
Despite the narrator's reluctance, they continue to an apartment building in the West Hundreds.
Myrtle exits the cab haughtily with her purchases and the dog.
In the elevator, she announces plans to invite the McKees and call her sister.
The apartment is on the top floor and described as small and cramped, filled with oversized, ornate furniture.
An enlarged, blurry photograph is the only picture.
Copies of gossip magazines lie on a table.
Myrtle attends to the new puppy's needs, tasking an elevator boy with getting supplies.
Tom retrieves a bottle of whiskey from a locked cabinet.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Meanwhile Tom brought out a bottle of whisky from a locked bureau door.

events.text_segment:
We drove over to Fifth Avenue, warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon. I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great flock of white sheep turn the corner.
“Hold on,” I said, “I have to leave you here.”
“No you don’t,” interposed Tom quickly. “Myrtle’ll be hurt if you don’t come up to the apartment. Won’t you, Myrtle?”
“Come on,” she urged. “I’ll telephone my sister Catherine. She’s said to be very beautiful by people who ought to know.”
“Well, I’d like to, but—”
We went on, cutting back again over the Park toward the West Hundreds. At 158th Street the cab stopped at one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses. Throwing a regal homecoming glance around the neighbourhood, Mrs. Wilson gathered up her dog and her other purchases, and went haughtily in.
“I’m going to have the McKees come up,” she announced as we rose in the elevator. “And, of course, I got to call up my sister, too.”
The apartment was on the top floor—a small living-room, a small dining-room, a small bedroom, and a bath. The living-room was crowded to the doors with a set of tapestried furniture entirely too large for it, so that to move about was to stumble continually over scenes of ladies swinging in the gardens of Versailles. The only picture was an over-enlarged photograph, apparently a hen sitting on a blurred rock. Looked at from a distance, however, the hen resolved itself into a bonnet, and the countenance of a stout old lady beamed down into the room. Several old copies of Town Tattle lay on the table together with a copy of Simon Called Peter, and some of the small scandal magazines of Broadway. Mrs. Wilson was first concerned with the dog. A reluctant elevator boy went for a box full of straw and some milk, to which he added on his own initiative a tin of large, hard dog biscuits—one of which decomposed apathetically in the saucer of milk all afternoon. Meanwhile Tom brought out a bottle of whisky from a locked bureau door.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
We drove over to Fifth Avenue, so warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon that I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great flock of white sheep turn the corner. “Hold on,” said Tom, “I want to get one of those dogs.”

So we stopped and he bought a dog from a man on the sidewalk. The man peered doubtfully at the basket, then at Tom, and finally at Myrtle, who was haughtily examining the contents of her bag. Tom handed the man a bill, and the three of us got back into the taxi, the little dog squirming and yapping in Myrtle’s lap.

I wanted to get out and walk eastward toward the park, but Tom insisted that I come up to the apartment. “You can’t offend her,” he said. “She’ll be hurt if you don’t.” Myrtle turned to me and said, “I’ll call my sister Catherine. She’s said to be very beautiful by people who ought to know.”

We drove on, crossing the city, until we came to the West Hundreds, where Tom led the way into a brownstone. Myrtle swept out of the cab with her purchases and the dog, and we followed her up the steps. In the elevator, she told the boy to hurry up, and announced that she was going to call her sister and invite the McKees, who lived one floor below.

The apartment was on the top floor—a small living room, a small dining room, a small bedroom, and a bath. The living room was crowded to the doors with a set of tapestried furniture entirely too large for it, so that to move about was to stumble continually over scenes of ladies swinging in the gardens of Versailles. The only picture was an over-enlarged photograph, blurred as though it had been taken from a moving train. On the table lay a copy of Town Tattle and a moving-picture magazine, and a bowl of dog biscuits.

Myrtle took the dog into the bathroom and powdered its nose with a small, dark powder puff. Then she flounced back into the living room and told the elevator boy to go to the drug store for a box of straw-colored towels and some ice. Tom brought out a bottle of whiskey from a locked bureau door.

We drove over to Fifth Avenue, so warm and soft, almost pastoral, on the summer Sunday afternoon that I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great flock of white sheep turn the corner. Hold on," I said, "I have to leave you here." "No, you don’t," interposed Tom quickly. "Myrtle’ll be hurt if you don’t come up to the apartment. Won’t you, Myrtle?"

"Come on," she urged. "I’ll telephone my sister Catherine. She’s said to be very beautiful by people who ought to know."

We stopped at the corner of one of the block-long white apartment houses at 158th Street. I was first to get out of the taxi, but I had no intention of being the first to go in. Myrtle, who had changed her costume some time before, was now attired in an elaborate afternoon dress of cream-colored chiffon, which gave out a continual rustle as she swept about the room. With the influence of the dress her personality had also undergone a change. The intense vitality that had been so remarkable in the garage was converted into impressive hauteur. Her laughter, her gestures, her assertions became more violently affected moment by moment.

As she entered the building she threw a regal glance at the surroundings, and, gathering up her dog and other purchases, swept into the elevator, followed by Tom and myself. "My sister and Mr. and Mrs. McKee are coming up," she announced. "And I want the boy to get some ice and mineral water right away."

The apartment was on the top floor—a small living room, a small dining room, a small bedroom, and a bath. The living room was crowded to the doors with a set of tapestried furniture entirely too large for it, so that to move about was to stumble continually over scenes of ladies swinging in the gardens of Versailles. The only picture was an over-enlarged photograph, apparently a hen sitting on a blurred rock. Looked at from a distance, however, the hen resolved itself into a bonnet, and the countenance of a stout old lady beamed down into the room.

Several old copies of "Town Tattle" lay on the table together with a copy of "Simon Called Peter," and some of the small scandal magazines of Broadway. Mrs. Wilson had changed her costume some time before, and was now attired in an elaborate afternoon dress of cream-colored chiffon, which gave out a continual rustle as she swept about the room. With the influence of the dress her personality had also undergone a change. The intense vitality that had been so remarkable in the garage was converted into impressive hauteur. Her laughter, her gestures, her assertions became more violently affected moment by moment.

The dog was sitting on a table looking with blind eyes through the smoke, and from time to time groaning faintly. People disappeared into the bathroom with towels wrapped high over their heads, and the little dog, sitting in a corner, looked up at them with dim, bewildered eyes. Tom brought out a bottle of whiskey from a locked bureau door.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I wouldn’t have been surprised to see a great flock of white sheep turn the corner. As Gatsby and I inched along through the lazy traffic, I was reminded of the city’s constant shifting, its restless energy subdued for a moment by the golden haze of the afternoon. The buildings, usually so imposing, seemed to recede into the background, softened by the sunlight and the gentle breeze that drifted in through the open windows of the car.

Gatsby sat beside me, his eyes fixed ahead, but I could sense the tension in his posture. He was dressed in his usual impeccable style, but there was a nervousness about him, a sense of anticipation that seemed to vibrate in the air between us. Every so often, he would glance at his watch, as if measuring the minutes until he would see Daisy again.

We passed a group of children playing on the sidewalk, their laughter ringing out above the hum of the city. An old man dozed on a bench beneath a tree, his hat tipped forward to shield his face from the sun. The city, for all its grandeur and ambition, seemed for a moment to belong to these ordinary people, their lives unfolding quietly against the backdrop of Fifth Avenue.

As we approached the corner where Daisy and Tom’s apartment stood, Gatsby’s grip on the steering wheel tightened. He turned to me, his voice low and urgent. “Do you think she’ll be glad to see me?” he asked, his eyes searching mine for reassurance.

I nodded, though I wasn’t sure. The events of the past few days had left me uncertain, caught between Gatsby’s dreams and the reality that seemed to press in on all sides. But in that moment, with the sunlight streaming through the windows and the city holding its breath, anything seemed possible.

We pulled up to the curb, and Gatsby stepped out, straightening his jacket and smoothing his hair. He paused for a moment, gathering himself, before turning to face the building where Daisy waited, his heart full of hope and longing.

events.title: The Apartment Party: Guests and Atmosphere
detailed_summary: The narrator reflects this is only the second time he has been drunk, casting the afternoon's events in a hazy light.
Myrtle sits on Tom's lap while making phone calls.
The narrator briefly leaves to buy cigarettes and returns to find Tom and Myrtle gone momentarily.
He sits and tries to read a book, finding it nonsensical, possibly due to the whiskey.
Tom and Myrtle reappear just as guests begin to arrive.
Myrtle's sister, Catherine, arrives—a worldly woman with striking red hair, artificial eyebrows, and noisy jewelry.
Catherine acts possessively in the apartment but confirms she lives elsewhere.
Mr. McKee, a pale photographer from downstairs, arrives, appearing freshly shaved and respectful.
Mrs. McKee—shrill, languid, and described as horrible—joins him.
Myrtle reappears, having changed into an elaborate cream dress that rustles as she moves.
Her demeanor transforms with the dress, becoming noticeably haughty and affected.
Her gestures and assertions grow louder and more artificial, dominating the small space.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I have been drunk just twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon; so everything that happened has a dim, hazy cast over it, although until after eight o’clock the apartment was full of cheerful sun.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Her laughter, her gestures, her assertions became more violently affected moment by moment, and as she expanded the room grew smaller around her, until she seemed to be revolving on a noisy, creaking pivot through the smoky air.

events.text_segment:
I have been drunk just twice in my life, and the second time was that afternoon; so everything that happened has a dim, hazy cast over it, although until after eight o’clock the apartment was full of cheerful sun. Sitting on Tom’s lap Mrs. Wilson called up several people on the telephone; then there were no cigarettes, and I went out to buy some at the drugstore on the corner. When I came back they had both disappeared, so I sat down discreetly in the living-room and read a chapter of Simon Called Peter—either it was terrible stuff or the whisky distorted things, because it didn’t make any sense to me.
Just as Tom and Myrtle (after the first drink Mrs. Wilson and I called each other by our first names) reappeared, company commenced to arrive at the apartment door.
The sister, Catherine, was a slender, worldly girl of about thirty, with a solid, sticky bob of red hair, and a complexion powdered milky white. Her eyebrows had been plucked and then drawn on again at a more rakish angle, but the efforts of nature toward the restoration of the old alignment gave a blurred air to her face. When she moved about there was an incessant clicking as innumerable pottery bracelets jingled up and down upon her arms. She came in with such a proprietary haste, and looked around so possessively at the furniture that I wondered if she lived here. But when I asked her she laughed immoderately, repeated my question aloud, and told me she lived with a girl friend at a hotel.
Mr. McKee was a pale, feminine man from the flat below. He had just shaved, for there was a white spot of lather on his cheekbone, and he was most respectful in his greeting to everyone in the room. He informed me that he was in the “artistic game,” and I gathered later that he was a photographer and had made the dim enlargement of Mrs. Wilson’s mother which hovered like an ectoplasm on the wall. His wife was shrill, languid, handsome, and horrible. She told me with pride that her husband had photographed her a hundred and twenty-seven times since they had been married.
Mrs. Wilson had changed her costume some time before, and was now attired in an elaborate afternoon dress of cream-coloured chiffon, which gave out a continual rustle as she swept about the room. With the influence of the dress her personality had also undergone a change. The intense vitality that had been so remarkable in the garage was converted into impressive hauteur. Her laughter, her gestures, her assertions became more violently affected moment by moment, and as she expanded the room grew smaller around her, until she seemed to be revolving on a noisy, creaking pivot through the smoky air.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
At first, I was aware only of the laughter and the clinking of glasses, the way the sunlight slanted through the windows and caught the dust motes in the air, making them shimmer like tiny golden insects. Myrtle Wilson, flushed with excitement and gin, was holding court in the center of the room, her voice rising above the others as she recounted some story about a trip to the city. Tom Buchanan lounged on the couch, his heavy-lidded eyes following her with a mixture of amusement and possessiveness. The little dog, forgotten for the moment, nosed around the edges of the room, occasionally yapping at a stray shoe or a dangling tassel.

I found myself sitting beside Catherine, Myrtle’s sister, who leaned in close to me, her breath warm and sweet with the scent of whiskey. She was telling me about her plans to go to Europe, about the men she knew and the parties she had attended, but her words seemed to float past me, indistinct and dreamlike. The room was growing warmer, the air thick with smoke and perfume, and I felt myself slipping further into a pleasant, detached stupor.

At some point, the conversation turned to Gatsby. Catherine insisted that he was related to the Kaiser, or perhaps a cousin of the devil himself, and the others laughed, their voices echoing strangely in my ears. Myrtle, emboldened by drink, began to talk about her marriage, her voice rising in pitch as she described her husband’s shortcomings. Tom’s face darkened, and for a moment I thought there might be trouble, but then someone suggested another round of drinks, and the tension dissolved into laughter once more.

The afternoon wore on, the sunlight fading from gold to amber to a dusky rose. The room grew louder, the laughter more raucous, and I found myself drifting from one conversation to another, never quite able to focus on any one thing. At some point, Myrtle changed her dress, emerging from the bedroom in a new outfit, her face flushed and her eyes shining. She perched on Tom’s lap, her arm draped around his shoulders, and for a moment they looked almost like a real couple, caught up in their own private world.

It was only later, as the shadows lengthened and the city lights began to twinkle outside the window, that the mood shifted. Voices grew sharper, tempers flared, and suddenly Tom was on his feet, his hand raised, and Myrtle was crying out, her voice raw and wounded. The spell was broken, and I found myself stumbling out into the night, the cool air a shock after the heat and noise of the apartment, my head spinning with gin and confusion.

events.title: Party Conversations: Gossip, Lies, and Class
detailed_summary: Myrtle complains loudly about the cost of a foot-care specialist.
Mrs. McKee compliments Myrtle's dress, which Myrtle dismisses as insignificant.
Mrs. McKee suggests her husband, Chester, could photograph Myrtle in that pose.
Mr. McKee contemplates the lighting and composition for a potential photograph of Myrtle.
Tom interrupts the artistic discussion by calling for more drinks.
Myrtle complains about service staff before dramatically going to the kitchen.
Mr. McKee attempts to engage Tom about his photography work on Long Island, mentioning two framed studies.
Tom responds with disinterest.
Catherine sits beside the narrator, inquiring about his residence and mentioning attending a party at Gatsby's.
She shares gossip that Gatsby is related to Kaiser Wilhelm and implies he is dangerous.
Mrs. McKee interrupts, suggesting Catherine as a photographic subject, but Mr. McKee focuses on networking with Tom.
Tom mockingly suggests Myrtle provide McKee with an introduction to her husband for a photo series.
Catherine whispers to the narrator that neither Tom nor Myrtle can stand their respective spouses and should divorce and marry each other.
Myrtle overhears a question about her feelings for Wilson and responds crudely.
Catherine falsely claims Tom's wife, Daisy, is Catholic and prevents the divorce.
The narrator knows Daisy isn't Catholic and is shocked by the lie.
Catherine adds that Tom and Myrtle plan to move West after marrying.
Catherine recounts a trip to Monte Carlo.
Mrs. McKee shares a story about nearly marrying a man she considered beneath her.
Myrtle relates this to her own marriage, stating she married Wilson thinking he was a gentleman of good breeding but found him unfit.
Catherine reminds Myrtle she was initially infatuated with Wilson.
Myrtle denies this vehemently, pointing at the narrator as someone she cares for just as little.
She claims her mistake was immediate, recounting discovering Wilson borrowed his wedding suit and crying all afternoon after returning it.

events.text_segment:
“My dear,” she told her sister in a high, mincing shout, “most of these fellas will cheat you every time. All they think of is money. I had a woman up here last week to look at my feet, and when she gave me the bill you’d of thought she had my appendicitis out.”
“What was the name of the woman?” asked Mrs. McKee.
“Mrs. Eberhardt. She goes around looking at people’s feet in their own homes.”
“I like your dress,” remarked Mrs. McKee, “I think it’s adorable.”
Mrs. Wilson rejected the compliment by raising her eyebrow in disdain.
“It’s just a crazy old thing,” she said. “I just slip it on sometimes when I don’t care what I look like.”
“But it looks wonderful on you, if you know what I mean,” pursued Mrs. McKee. “If Chester could only get you in that pose I think he could make something of it.”
We all looked in silence at Mrs. Wilson, who removed a strand of hair from over her eyes and looked back at us with a brilliant smile. Mr. McKee regarded her intently with his head on one side, and then moved his hand back and forth slowly in front of his face.
“I should change the light,” he said after a moment. “I’d like to bring out the modelling of the features. And I’d try to get hold of all the back hair.”
“I wouldn’t think of changing the light,” cried Mrs. McKee. “I think it’s—”
Her husband said “Sh!” and we all looked at the subject again, whereupon Tom Buchanan yawned audibly and got to his feet.
“You McKees have something to drink,” he said. “Get some more ice and mineral water, Myrtle, before everybody goes to sleep.”
“I told that boy about the ice.” Myrtle raised her eyebrows in despair at the shiftlessness of the lower orders. “These people! You have to keep after them all the time.”
She looked at me and laughed pointlessly. Then she flounced over to the dog, kissed it with ecstasy, and swept into the kitchen, implying that a dozen chefs awaited her orders there.
“I’ve done some nice things out on Long Island,” asserted Mr. McKee.
Tom looked at him blankly.
“Two of them we have framed downstairs.”
“Two what?” demanded Tom.
“Two studies. One of them I call Montauk Point—The Gulls, and the other I call Montauk Point—The Sea.”
The sister Catherine sat down beside me on the couch.
“Do you live down on Long Island, too?” she inquired.
“I live at West Egg.”
“Really? I was down there at a party about a month ago. At a man named Gatsby’s. Do you know him?”
“I live next door to him.”
“Well, they say he’s a nephew or a cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm’s. That’s where all his money comes from.”
“Really?”
She nodded.
“I’m scared of him. I’d hate to have him get anything on me.”
This absorbing information about my neighbour was interrupted by Mrs. McKee’s pointing suddenly at Catherine:
“Chester, I think you could do something with her,” she broke out, but Mr. McKee only nodded in a bored way, and turned his attention to Tom.
“I’d like to do more work on Long Island, if I could get the entry. All I ask is that they should give me a start.”
“Ask Myrtle,” said Tom, breaking into a short shout of laughter as Mrs. Wilson entered with a tray. “She’ll give you a letter of introduction, won’t you, Myrtle?”
“Do what?” she asked, startled.
“You’ll give McKee a letter of introduction to your husband, so he can do some studies of him.” His lips moved silently for a moment as he invented, “ ‘George B. Wilson at the Gasoline Pump,’ or something like that.”
Catherine leaned close to me and whispered in my ear:
“Neither of them can stand the person they’re married to.”
“Can’t they?”
“Can’t stand them.” She looked at Myrtle and then at Tom. “What I say is, why go on living with them if they can’t stand them? If I was them I’d get a divorce and get married to each other right away.”
“Doesn’t she like Wilson either?”
The answer to this was unexpected. It came from Myrtle, who had overheard the question, and it was violent and obscene.
“You see,” cried Catherine triumphantly. She lowered her voice again. “It’s really his wife that’s keeping them apart. She’s a Catholic, and they don’t believe in divorce.”
Daisy was not a Catholic, and I was a little shocked at the elaborateness of the lie.
“When they do get married,” continued Catherine, “they’re going West to live for a while until it blows over.”
“It’d be more discreet to go to Europe.”
“Oh, do you like Europe?” she exclaimed surprisingly. “I just got back from Monte Carlo.”
“Really.”
“Just last year. I went over there with another girl.”
“Stay long?”
“No, we just went to Monte Carlo and back. We went by way of Marseilles. We had over twelve hundred dollars when we started, but we got gyped out of it all in two days in the private rooms. We had an awful time getting back, I can tell you. God, how I hated that town!”
The late afternoon sky bloomed in the window for a moment like the blue honey of the Mediterranean—then the shrill voice of Mrs. McKee called me back into the room.
“I almost made a mistake, too,” she declared vigorously. “I almost married a little kike who’d been after me for years. I knew he was below me. Everybody kept saying to me: ‘Lucille, that man’s way below you!’ But if I hadn’t met Chester, he’d of got me sure.”
“Yes, but listen,” said Myrtle Wilson, nodding her head up and down, “at least you didn’t marry him.”
“I know I didn’t.”
“Well, I married him,” said Myrtle, ambiguously. “And that’s the difference between your case and mine.”
“Why did you, Myrtle?” demanded Catherine. “Nobody forced you to.”
Myrtle considered.
“I married him because I thought he was a gentleman,” she said finally. “I thought he knew something about breeding, but he wasn’t fit to lick my shoe.”
“You were crazy about him for a while,” said Catherine.
“Crazy about him!” cried Myrtle incredulously. “Who said I was crazy about him? I never was any more crazy about him than I was about that man there.”
She pointed suddenly at me, and everyone looked at me accusingly. I tried to show by my expression that I expected no affection.
“The only crazy I was was when I married him. I knew right away I made a mistake. He borrowed somebody’s best suit to get married in, and never even told me about it, and the man came after it one day when he was out: ‘Oh, is that your suit?’ I said. ‘This is the first I ever heard about it.’ But I gave it to him and then I lay down and cried to beat the band all afternoon.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
“My dear,” she told her sister in a high, mincing shout, “most of these fellas will cheat you every time. All they think of is money. I had a woman up here last week to look at my feet, and when she gave me the bill you’d of thought she had my appendicitis out.”

“What was the name of the woman?” asked Mrs. McKee.

“Mrs. Eberhardt. She goes around looking at people’s feet in their own homes.”

“I like your dress,” remarked Mrs. McKee, “I think it’s adorable.”

Mrs. Wilson rejected the compliment by raising her eyebrow in disdain. “It’s just a crazy old thing,” she said. “I just slip it on sometimes when I don’t care what I look like.”

“But it looks wonderful on you, if you know what I mean,” pursued Mrs. McKee.

“If Chester could only get you in that pose I think he could make something of it.”

We all looked in silence at Mrs. Wilson who removed a strand of hair from over her eyes and looked back at us with a brilliant smile. Mr. McKee regarded her intently with his head on one side and then moved his hand back and forth slowly in front of his face.

“I should change the light,” he said after a moment. “I’d like to bring out the modeling of the features. And I’d try to get hold of all the back hair.”

“I wouldn’t think of changing the light,” cried Mrs. McKee. “I think it’s—”

Her husband said “Sh!” and we all looked at the subject again, whereupon Tom Buchanan yawned audibly and got to his feet.

“You McKees have something to drink,” he said. “Get some more ice and mineral water, Myrtle, before everybody goes to sleep.”

“I told that boy about the ice.” Myrtle raised her eyebrows in despair at the shiftlessness of the lower orders. “These people! You have to keep after them all the time.” She looked at me and laughed pointlessly. Then she flounced over to the dog and sat down with it in her lap, stroking it and looking at Tom. “I’ll get some more ice and mineral water,” she said, and went out into the hall.

“Really, I’m not even faintly like a rose.” She threw back her head and laughed. “I’m going to make a list of all the things I’ve got to get.”

“A little dog,” said Tom, “that’s all she wants.”

“Is it a boy or a girl?”

“That dog? That dog’s a boy.”

“It’s a bitch,” said Tom decisively. “Here’s your money. Go and buy ten more dogs with it.”

“We’re getting off,” he insisted. “I want you to meet my girl.”

Mr. McKee was asleep on a chair with his fists clenched in his lap, like a photograph of a man of action. Taking out my handkerchief I wiped from his cheek the remains of the spot of dried lather that had worried me all the afternoon.

The little dog was sitting on the table looking with blind eyes through the smoke, and from time to time groaning faintly. People disappeared, reappeared, made plans to go somewhere, and then lost each other, searched for each other, found each other a few feet away.

Sometime toward midnight Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson stood face to face discussing, in impassioned voices, whether Mrs. Wilson had any right to mention Daisy’s name.

“Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!” shouted Mrs. Wilson. “I’ll say it whenever I want to! Daisy! Dai——”

Making a short deft movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with his open hand.

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion omits a substantial portion of the original passage, particularly the entire middle and end sections. Key conversations, character interactions, and narrative developments are missing, including discussions about Long Island, Gatsby, marital relationships, and the Monte Carlo anecdote.
- The completion invents a sequence involving Myrtle sitting with the dog and a conversation about the dog's gender and buying more dogs, which does not occur in the original at this point. It also introduces a scene with Mr. McKee asleep and the narrator wiping his cheek, which is not present in this segment of the original.
- The ending of the completion jumps to a later, unrelated event (the altercation between Tom and Myrtle), which is not part of the original passage provided.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion lacks the extended dialogue about Gatsby, rumors about his background, and Catherine's opinions on marriage and divorce.
- There is no mention of the conversation about Mr. McKee's artwork, his desire to work on Long Island, or Tom's sarcastic suggestion regarding a letter of introduction.
- The completion omits the detailed exchange about Catherine's trip to Monte Carlo, the financial loss, and her feelings about the experience.
- The original's nuanced discussion about Myrtle's marriage, her regrets, and the anecdote about the borrowed suit are entirely absent.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The sequence of events is incorrect: the completion introduces invented scenes and skips over large sections of the original narrative, disrupting the flow and chronology.
- There are invented actions and dialogue, such as Myrtle's interaction with the dog and the discussion about buying more dogs, which do not align with the original content.
- The completion inaccurately places the physical altercation between Tom and Myrtle, which occurs much later in the book, not in this passage.
- Some character actions and attributions are misplaced or fabricated, such as the narrator's actions toward Mr. McKee and the dog's behavior.

To improve, the LLM should focus on accurately following the sequence and content of the original passage, avoid inventing scenes or dialogue, and ensure all major conversations and character interactions are included in the correct order.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
My dear,” she told her sister in a high, mincing shout, “most of these fellas will cheat you every time. Just as soon as they find out you’re not some little fool, they’ll try to take advantage. You have to keep your wits about you.”

Daisy, lounging on the enormous couch, let out a little laugh, the sound floating through the room like a soft bell. “Oh, Jordan, you always think the worst of people. I think they’re just bored, that’s all. Bored and looking for something to do.”

Jordan Baker, tall and slender, with a chin raised in perpetual skepticism, shrugged her bare shoulders. “Maybe. But I’ve seen enough to know. You can’t trust them, Daisy. Not with anything that matters.”

The room was filled with the golden light of late afternoon, filtered through the billowing curtains that stirred in the breeze. The air was heavy with the scent of roses from the garden, and the distant sound of laughter drifted in from the lawn, where Tom Buchanan and Nick Carraway were talking in low voices.

Daisy turned her head, her eyes following the sound. “Tom’s always so serious with Nick. I wonder what they’re talking about.”

Jordan smiled, a little crookedly. “Probably about money, or horses, or something equally dull. Men are like that.”

Daisy sighed, her fingers tracing idle patterns on the embroidered cushion. “Sometimes I wish things were different. That we could just—start over, somehow.”

Jordan looked at her, her expression softening. “You can’t repeat the past, Daisy.”

“Can’t I?” Daisy’s voice was wistful, almost pleading. “Sometimes I feel like I’m just waiting for something to happen. Something wonderful and impossible.”

Jordan reached over and took Daisy’s hand. “You have everything anyone could want. A beautiful house, a husband, a little girl. What more is there?”

Daisy looked away, her eyes shining with unshed tears. “I don’t know. I just—sometimes I feel so alone.”

The sound of footsteps in the hallway made them both look up. Tom and Nick entered, Tom’s face flushed from the sun, Nick’s expression thoughtful.

“Everything all right in here?” Tom asked, his voice booming in the quiet room.

“Of course,” Daisy said quickly, her smile bright and brittle. “We were just talking.”

Tom glanced at Jordan, then at Daisy, suspicion flickering in his eyes. “About what?”

“About life,” Jordan said smoothly. “And how complicated it can be.”

Tom snorted. “Life’s only as complicated as you make it. I say, keep things simple.”

Nick, sensing the tension, tried to change the subject. “It’s a beautiful day. Shall we go out to the garden?”

Daisy stood, smoothing her dress. “Yes, let’s. I need some fresh air.”

They made their way outside, the sunlight dazzling after the dimness of the house. The garden was a riot of color, the flowers nodding in the breeze, the grass soft underfoot. Daisy wandered ahead, her white dress billowing around her like a cloud.

Nick watched her, struck by the fragility of her beauty, the way she seemed to float through the world, untouched by its harshness. He wondered what secrets she carried, what dreams she had buried beneath her laughter.

Tom and Jordan followed, their voices low and conspiratorial. Nick lagged behind, lost in thought.

As they reached the edge of the lawn, a car pulled up to the drive, its engine purring softly. A man stepped out, tall and impeccably dressed, his eyes hidden behind dark glasses.

Daisy stopped, her hand flying to her mouth. “Gatsby!”

The name hung in the air, electric and charged with meaning. Tom stiffened, his jaw tightening.

Gatsby approached, his movements graceful and assured. He smiled at Daisy, a smile that seemed to light up the world.

“Hello, Daisy.”

She took a step toward him, her eyes wide and shining. “Hello, Jay.”

Tom watched them, his face darkening. “What are you doing here, Gatsby?”

Gatsby’s gaze never left Daisy. “I came to see if you were all right.”

Daisy laughed, a little breathlessly. “I’m fine. Everything’s fine.”

Gatsby nodded, his expression unreadable. “I’m glad.”

There was a silence, heavy and expectant. Jordan glanced at Nick, her eyebrows raised.

Finally, Tom spoke, his voice cold. “We were just about to have tea. Would you care to join us, Gatsby?”

Gatsby hesitated, then nodded. “Thank you.”

They returned to the house, the atmosphere charged with tension. Daisy sat beside Gatsby, her hand trembling slightly as she poured the tea. Tom watched them, his eyes narrowed.

Nick tried to make conversation, but the words fell flat. The air was thick with unspoken words, with longing and regret.

After a while, Gatsby stood. “I should be going.”

Daisy looked up at him, her eyes pleading. “Don’t go.”

Gatsby hesitated, then sat down again. “All right.”

Tom stood abruptly. “I need a drink.” He strode from the room, his footsteps echoing down the hall.

Jordan leaned over to Daisy. “Are you all right?”

Daisy nodded, but her smile was shaky. “I just—I didn’t expect to see him.”

Gatsby reached for her hand, his touch gentle. “I only wanted to see you. To make sure you’re happy.”

Daisy looked at him, her eyes filling with tears. “Oh, Jay. I don’t know what I am.”

Nick watched them, feeling like an intruder in a private moment. He wondered if happiness was ever really possible, or if it was just an illusion, a dream that slipped through your fingers no matter how tightly you held on.

The afternoon faded into evening, the sky streaked with gold and pink. The house was quiet, the only sound the distant hum of the city beyond the trees.

As the first stars appeared, Gatsby stood. “I should go.”

Daisy rose, her hand still in his. “Will I see you again?”

Gatsby smiled, a little sadly. “Whenever you want.”

She watched him go, her heart aching with longing and regret. Nick stood beside her, silent and understanding.

Jordan joined them, her face thoughtful. “He loves you, you know.”

Daisy nodded, tears slipping down her cheeks. “I know. But love isn’t always enough.”

They stood together in the gathering darkness, the past and the future stretching out before them, uncertain and full of possibility.

events.title: Myrtle's Story and Rising Tension
detailed_summary: Catherine reiterates to the narrator that Myrtle should leave Wilson, mentioning their eleven years living over the garage and that Tom is her first 'sweetie'.
A second bottle of whiskey circulates; only Catherine abstains.
Tom orders sandwiches.
The narrator repeatedly tries to leave but gets drawn back into loud arguments.
He reflects on being both 'within and without,' simultaneously involved and observing the scene, imagining how their lighted window appears to outsiders.
Myrtle moves close to the narrator and shares the story of her first encounter with Tom on a train.
She describes feeling an immediate attraction to his appearance and presence.
She recounts their interaction leading to a shared taxi ride, feeling exhilarated by the illicit thrill and the thought 'You can’t live forever'.
After telling the story, Myrtle laughs artificially and tells Mrs. McKee she plans to give her the dress she is wearing.
She begins listing things she needs to buy: a massage, hair appointment, dog collar, ashtray, and a wreath for her mother's grave.
Time passes quickly; it is suddenly ten o'clock.
Mr. McKee is asleep in a chair.
The narrator wipes a spot of dried shaving lather from McKee's cheek.
The party grows chaotic, with people disappearing and reappearing.
Towards midnight, Tom and Myrtle argue heatedly about whether Myrtle has the right to say Daisy's name.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “She really ought to get away from him,” resumed Catherine to me.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Some time toward midnight Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson stood face to face discussing, in impassioned voices, whether Mrs. Wilson had any right to mention Daisy’s name.

events.text_segment:
“She really ought to get away from him,” resumed Catherine to me. “They’ve been living over that garage for eleven years. And Tom’s the first sweetie she ever had.”
The bottle of whisky—a second one—was now in constant demand by all present, excepting Catherine, who “felt just as good on nothing at all.” Tom rang for the janitor and sent him for some celebrated sandwiches, which were a complete supper in themselves. I wanted to get out and walk eastward toward the park through the soft twilight, but each time I tried to go I became entangled in some wild, strident argument which pulled me back, as if with ropes, into my chair. Yet high over the city our line of yellow windows must have contributed their share of human secrecy to the casual watcher in the darkening streets, and I saw him too, looking up and wondering. I was within and without, simultaneously enchanted and repelled by the inexhaustible variety of life.
Myrtle pulled her chair close to mine, and suddenly her warm breath poured over me the story of her first meeting with Tom.
“It was on the two little seats facing each other that are always the last ones left on the train. I was going up to New York to see my sister and spend the night. He had on a dress suit and patent leather shoes, and I couldn’t keep my eyes off him, but every time he looked at me I had to pretend to be looking at the advertisement over his head. When we came into the station he was next to me, and his white shirtfront pressed against my arm, and so I told him I’d have to call a policeman, but he knew I lied. I was so excited that when I got into a taxi with him I didn’t hardly know I wasn’t getting into a subway train. All I kept thinking about, over and over, was ‘You can’t live forever; you can’t live forever.’ ”
She turned to Mrs. McKee and the room rang full of her artificial laughter.
“My dear,” she cried, “I’m going to give you this dress as soon as I’m through with it. I’ve got to get another one tomorrow. I’m going to make a list of all the things I’ve got to get. A massage and a wave, and a collar for the dog, and one of those cute little ashtrays where you touch a spring, and a wreath with a black silk bow for mother’s grave that’ll last all summer. I got to write down a list so I won’t forget all the things I got to do.”
It was nine o’clock—almost immediately afterward I looked at my watch and found it was ten. Mr. McKee was asleep on a chair with his fists clenched in his lap, like a photograph of a man of action. Taking out my handkerchief I wiped from his cheek the spot of dried lather that had worried me all the afternoon.
The little dog was sitting on the table looking with blind eyes through the smoke, and from time to time groaning faintly. People disappeared, reappeared, made plans to go somewhere, and then lost each other, searched for each other, found each other a few feet away. Some time toward midnight Tom Buchanan and Mrs. Wilson stood face to face discussing, in impassioned voices, whether Mrs. Wilson had any right to mention Daisy’s name.

IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- The completion introduces a new event not present in the original: the narrator sitting down to read a chapter of a specific book and reflecting on its quality. This invented scene disrupts the flow and adds content that was not part of the original passage.
- The sequence of the party breaking up is misplaced; in the original, the narrative continues with the party's progression and the argument between Tom and Mrs. Wilson, rather than indicating the party is ending at that point.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion omits the narrator's observation about the passage of time, specifically the moment of checking the watch and the time jump from one hour to the next.
- The list Myrtle recites is incomplete; several items she intends to purchase or do are missing, particularly those mentioned later in her speech.
- The completion does not include the narrator's internal experience of being pulled back into arguments whenever attempting to leave, which is a key part of the original's middle section.
- The subtle description of the windows' contribution to the city's secrecy and the narrator's dual perspective (being both observer and participant) is altered and partially omitted.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- There is an inaccurate depiction of the narrator's perspective regarding the watcher in the street; the completion changes the viewpoint and merges the narrator with the watcher, which is not consistent with the original.
- The sequence of events is altered: the mention of the party breaking up and the time of night occurs earlier than in the original, disrupting the intended narrative progression.
- The description of wiping the spot of dried lather from Mr. McKee's cheek is slightly inaccurate in its context and timing.
- The completion omits the narrator's reflection on the inexhaustible variety of life at the appropriate moment, and instead shifts focus to invented or misplaced content.
- The transition to the argument between Tom and Mrs. Wilson is less clear and lacks the buildup present in the original passage.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“She really ought to get away from him,” resumed Catherine to me. “They’re not happy, and neither of them is willing to admit it. Myrtle’s been talking about it for ten years. She says she’s going to leave him, but she never does. I suppose she’s afraid of what people would say, or maybe she’s just used to it by now.”

Catherine leaned forward, her voice dropping to a confidential tone. “You know, Tom’s the only man she’s ever really cared about. She says he’s different from her husband—more of a man, more exciting. I suppose that’s what draws her to him. But I don’t think it’s going to end well. Tom’s not the sort to leave his wife, not really. He likes the arrangement just as it is.”

I nodded, not quite sure what to say. The room was thick with the smell of stale smoke and perfume, and the laughter from the other side of the apartment seemed to grow louder, as if to drown out the uncomfortable truths being spoken in the corner.

Catherine took a sip of her drink and glanced over at Myrtle, who was laughing too loudly at something Tom had said. “She’s always wanted something more, you know. She grew up in a small town, and she’s never really gotten over it. She wants to be part of something bigger, something more glamorous. That’s why she’s with Tom. He represents everything she’s ever wanted.”

I looked at Myrtle, her face flushed with excitement, her eyes shining with a kind of desperate hope. It was clear that she was living for these moments, these stolen afternoons in the city, away from the drabness of her life in the valley of ashes.

Catherine sighed. “It’s all a mess, really. But what can you do? People make their choices, and then they have to live with them.”

At that moment, Tom called out to us, his voice booming across the room. “Come on, let’s have some music!” Someone turned on the radio, and the strains of a popular tune filled the apartment. Myrtle jumped up and began to dance, her movements wild and uninhibited. Tom watched her with a mixture of amusement and possessiveness, his eyes never leaving her.

The party grew louder, the drinks flowed more freely, and the atmosphere became increasingly chaotic. I found myself drifting to the window, looking out at the city below. The lights of New York twinkled in the distance, promising excitement and adventure, but also reminding me of the emptiness that seemed to lie at the heart of all this revelry.

As the evening wore on, the tensions in the room became more pronounced. Myrtle and Tom argued, their voices rising above the music. Catherine tried to intervene, but it was no use. The illusion of happiness that had briefly held the group together was beginning to unravel.

Eventually, the party broke up. People gathered their things and said their goodbyes, their faces tired and drawn. I left the apartment with a sense of unease, haunted by the knowledge that beneath the surface of all this glamour and excitement, there was a deep and abiding unhappiness.

As I walked back to my own apartment, I thought about what Catherine had said. People make their choices, and then they have to live with them. It was a sobering thought, and one that would stay with me long after the lights of the city had faded from view.

events.title: Violence Erupts and the Party Dissolves
detailed_summary: Myrtle defiantly shouts Daisy's name multiple times.
Tom reacts swiftly, striking Myrtle across the face with his open hand and breaking her nose.
The immediate aftermath involves bloody towels on the bathroom floor and the sounds of women scolding and Myrtle crying out in pain.
Mr. McKee awakens in a daze and starts to leave.
He pauses, observes the chaotic scene: his wife and Catherine tending to the bleeding Myrtle on the couch, who is trying to cover the Versailles tapestry with a gossip magazine.
Mr. McKee then continues out the door.
The narrator retrieves his hat and follows McKee.
In the elevator, McKee vaguely suggests getting lunch sometime.
The elevator operator reprimands McKee for touching the lever.
The narrator agrees to the lunch suggestion.
The narrative jumps, showing the narrator standing by McKee's bed as McKee, in his underwear, displays a portfolio of photographs with titles.
Finally, the narrator finds himself disoriented in the cold lower level of Pennsylvania Station early in the morning, reading a newspaper and waiting for the 4 a.m. train.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!” shouted Mrs. Wilson.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Then I was lying half asleep in the cold lower level of the Pennsylvania Station, staring at the morning Tribune, and waiting for the four o’clock train.

events.text_segment:
“Daisy! Daisy! Daisy!” shouted Mrs. Wilson. “I’ll say it whenever I want to! Daisy! Dai—”
Making a short deft movement, Tom Buchanan broke her nose with his open hand.
Then there were bloody towels upon the bathroom floor, and women’s voices scolding, and high over the confusion a long broken wail of pain. Mr. McKee awoke from his doze and started in a daze toward the door. When he had gone halfway he turned around and stared at the scene—his wife and Catherine scolding and consoling as they stumbled here and there among the crowded furniture with articles of aid, and the despairing figure on the couch, bleeding fluently, and trying to spread a copy of Town Tattle over the tapestry scenes of Versailles. Then Mr. McKee turned and continued on out the door. Taking my hat from the chandelier, I followed.
“Come to lunch some day,” he suggested, as we groaned down in the elevator.
“Where?”
“Anywhere.”
“Keep your hands off the lever,” snapped the elevator boy.
“I beg your pardon,” said Mr. McKee with dignity, “I didn’t know I was touching it.”
“All right,” I agreed, “I’ll be glad to.”
… I was standing beside his bed and he was sitting up between the sheets, clad in his underwear, with a great portfolio in his hands.
“Beauty and the Beast… Loneliness… Old Grocery Horse… Brook’n Bridge…”
Then I was lying half asleep in the cold lower level of the Pennsylvania Station, staring at the morning Tribune, and waiting for the four o’clock train.

events.title: Gatsby's Lavish Parties Described
detailed_summary: Music emanated from the neighbour's house during summer nights.
Guests, described metaphorically as moths, frequented his blue gardens amidst conversations, champagne, and stars.
During the day, guests enjoyed diving from a raft tower or sunbathing on his beach.
Gatsby's motorboats traversed the Sound, pulling aquaplanes.
On weekends, his Rolls-Royce transported groups to and from the city continuously, while his station wagon fetched guests from trains.
Every Monday, a large staff, including an extra gardener, worked to repair the weekend's festivities.
Large quantities of oranges and lemons were delivered weekly and juiced by a special machine.
Periodically, caterers set up extensive canvas tents and lighting.
Buffet tables featured elaborate food displays, including ornate salads and roasted meats.
A fully stocked bar with a brass rail offered a wide array of liquors, some unfamiliar to the younger guests.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was music from my neighbour’s house through the summer nights.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.

events.text_segment:
There was music from my neighbour’s house through the summer nights. In his blue gardens men and girls came and went like moths among the whisperings and the champagne and the stars. At high tide in the afternoon I watched his guests diving from the tower of his raft, or taking the sun on the hot sand of his beach while his two motorboats slit the waters of the Sound, drawing aquaplanes over cataracts of foam. On weekends his Rolls-Royce became an omnibus, bearing parties to and from the city between nine in the morning and long past midnight, while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains. And on Mondays eight servants, including an extra gardener, toiled all day with mops and scrubbing-brushes and hammers and garden-shears, repairing the ravages of the night before.
Every Friday five crates of oranges and lemons arrived from a fruiterer in New York—every Monday these same oranges and lemons left his back door in a pyramid of pulpless halves. There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler’s thumb.
At least once a fortnight a corps of caterers came down with several hundred feet of canvas and enough coloured lights to make a Christmas tree of Gatsby’s enormous garden. On buffet tables, garnished with glistening hors-d’oeuvre, spiced baked hams crowded against salads of harlequin designs and pastry pigs and turkeys bewitched to a dark gold. In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.

At high tide in the afternoon I watched his guests diving from the tower of his raft, or taking the sun on the hot sand of his beach while his two motor-boats slit the waters of the Sound, drawing aquaplanes over cataracts of foam. On weekends his Rolls-Royce became an omnibus, bearing parties to and from the city, between nine in the morning and long past midnight, while his station wagon scampered like a brisk yellow bug to meet all trains. And on Mondays eight servants, including an extra gardener, toiled all day with mops and scrubbing-brushes and hammers and garden-shears, repairing the ravages of the night before.

Every Friday five crates of oranges and lemons arrived from a fruiterer in New York—every Monday these same oranges and lemons left his back door in a pyramid of pulpless halves. There was a machine in the kitchen which could extract the juice of two hundred oranges in half an hour if a little button was pressed two hundred times by a butler’s thumb.

At least once a fortnight a corps of caterers came down with several hundred feet of canvas and enough colored lights to make a Christmas tree of Gatsby’s enormous garden. On buffet tables, garnished with glistening hors-d’oeuvre, spiced baked hams crowded against salads of harlequin designs and pastry pigs and turkeys bewitched to a dark gold. In the main hall a bar with a real brass rail was set up, and stocked with gins and liquors and with cordials so long forgotten that most of his female guests were too young to know one from another.

events.title: The Party Atmosphere Intensifies
detailed_summary: A large orchestra, not a small ensemble, arrived by seven o'clock.
Swimmers returned from the beach to dress, and numerous cars from New York filled the driveway.
Halls and verandas became vibrant with brightly dressed guests, modern hairstyles, and luxurious shawls.
The bar operated at full capacity, with cocktails circulating throughout the garden.
The air filled with lively chatter, laughter, brief introductions, and superficial encounters between strangers.
As night fell, the lights brightened, the orchestra played upbeat music, and conversation grew louder.
Laughter became more frequent and unrestrained.
Social groups formed, dissolved, and reformed rapidly with new arrivals.
Confident young women moved through the crowd, briefly becoming centers of attention before moving on.
One woman impulsively grabbed a cocktail, drank it quickly, and began dancing alone on a platform.
After a brief silence, the orchestra adapted its rhythm for her.
A rumor spread incorrectly that she was a famous dancer's understudy, marking the true commencement of the party.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The party has begun.

events.text_segment:
By seven o’clock the orchestra has arrived, no thin five-piece affair, but a whole pitful of oboes and trombones and saxophones and viols and cornets and piccolos, and low and high drums. The last swimmers have come in from the beach now and are dressing upstairs; the cars from New York are parked five deep in the drive, and already the halls and salons and verandas are gaudy with primary colours, and hair bobbed in strange new ways, and shawls beyond the dreams of Castile. The bar is in full swing, and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside, until the air is alive with chatter and laughter, and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot, and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other’s names.
The lights grow brighter as the earth lurches away from the sun, and now the orchestra is playing yellow cocktail music, and the opera of voices pitches a key higher. Laughter is easier minute by minute, spilled with prodigality, tipped out at a cheerful word. The groups change more swiftly, swell with new arrivals, dissolve and form in the same breath; already there are wanderers, confident girls who weave here and there among the stouter and more stable, become for a sharp, joyous moment the centre of a group, and then, excited with triumph, glide on through the sea-change of faces and voices and colour under the constantly changing light.
Suddenly one of these gypsies, in trembling opal, seizes a cocktail out of the air, dumps it down for courage and, moving her hands like Frisco, dances out alone on the canvas platform. A momentary hush; the orchestra leader varies his rhythm obligingly for her, and there is a burst of chatter as the erroneous news goes around that she is Gilda Gray’s understudy from the Follies. The party has begun.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The air is alive with the hum of tuning instruments, the clatter of cases, and the laughter of guests as they drift in from the gardens, drawn by the promise of music and the golden glow spilling from the house. The conductor, a portly man with a shock of white hair, raises his baton, and the orchestra launches into a lively jazz number that sets the whole room in motion. Couples swirl across the polished floor, their gowns and tuxedos catching the light, while others cluster around the buffet tables, sampling the endless array of delicacies and sipping champagne from tall, slender glasses.

Gatsby himself is nowhere to be seen, but his presence is felt in every detail—the lavish decorations, the attentive servants, the sense of anticipation that hangs in the air. The guests, most of whom have never met their host, speculate in hushed tones about his origins and his wealth. Some say he is a German spy, others that he killed a man once. The rumors swirl as freely as the drinks, adding an air of mystery to the festivities.

As the evening deepens, the music grows wilder, the laughter louder. Lanterns bob in the warm night breeze, casting shifting patterns of light and shadow across the lawns. Somewhere, a girl in a yellow dress stands on the marble steps, her laughter ringing out above the music. The party is in full swing, a dazzling spectacle of excess and possibility, and for a moment, it seems as if anything might happen under the watchful eyes of Gatsby’s house.

events.title: Nick Arrives at Gatsby's Party
detailed_summary: Nick reflects that he was likely one of the few attendees actually invited to Gatsby's parties.
He notes that most people simply showed up, arriving via car and finding their way to Gatsby's.
Upon arrival, guests were typically introduced by someone acquainted with Gatsby and then behaved freely, akin to being at an amusement park.
Many attendees never even met Gatsby, attending simply for the enjoyment of the party.
Nick confirms he received a formal invitation delivered by Gatsby's chauffeur earlier that Saturday.
The note expressed Gatsby's honor in inviting Nick to the 'little party' and mentioned prior intentions to meet, citing unspecified circumstances preventing it.
The invitation was signed by Jay Gatsby with a distinctive signature.
Dressed in white flannels, Nick went to Gatsby's around seven.
He felt uncomfortable amidst the unfamiliar crowd, though he recognized some faces from his commute.
Nick noticed many young Englishmen, well-dressed and seemingly eager, conversing intently with prosperous Americans.
He suspected they were involved in sales—bonds, insurance, or cars—keenly aware of the local wealth and hoping to capitalize on it.
Upon arriving, Nick tried to locate his host, Gatsby.
The few people he asked reacted with surprise and vehemently denied knowing Gatsby's location.
Feeling awkward, Nick retreated towards the cocktail table, seeing it as the only suitable place for a lone man to stand.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: As soon as I arrived I made an attempt to find my host, but the two or three people of whom I asked his whereabouts stared at me in such an amazed way, and denied so vehemently any knowledge of his movements, that I slunk off in the direction of the cocktail table—the only place in the garden where a single man could linger without looking purposeless and alone.

events.text_segment:
I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby’s house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby’s door. Once there they were introduced by somebody who knew Gatsby, and after that they conducted themselves according to the rules of behaviour associated with an amusement park. Sometimes they came and went without having met Gatsby at all, came for the party with a simplicity of heart that was its own ticket of admission.
I had been actually invited. A chauffeur in a uniform of robin’s-egg blue crossed my lawn early that Saturday morning with a surprisingly formal note from his employer: the honour would be entirely Gatsby’s, it said, if I would attend his “little party” that night. He had seen me several times, and had intended to call on me long before, but a peculiar combination of circumstances had prevented it—signed Jay Gatsby, in a majestic hand.
Dressed up in white flannels I went over to his lawn a little after seven, and wandered around rather ill at ease among swirls and eddies of people I didn’t know—though here and there was a face I had noticed on the commuting train. I was immediately struck by the number of young Englishmen dotted about; all well dressed, all looking a little hungry, and all talking in low, earnest voices to solid and prosperous Americans. I was sure that they were selling something: bonds or insurance or automobiles. They were at least agonizingly aware of the easy money in the vicinity and convinced that it was theirs for a few words in the right key.
As soon as I arrived I made an attempt to find my host, but the two or three people of whom I asked his whereabouts stared at me in such an amazed way, and denied so vehemently any knowledge of his movements, that I slunk off in the direction of the cocktail table—the only place in the garden where a single man could linger without looking purposeless and alone.

events.title: Nick Reunites with Jordan and Hears Gossip About Gatsby
detailed_summary: Feeling intensely embarrassed and contemplating getting drunk, Nick spots Jordan Baker emerging from the house.
Jordan stood at the top of the steps, observing the garden with detached curiosity.
Nick felt compelled to join someone to avoid awkwardness.
He greeted her loudly across the garden.
Jordan acknowledged him casually, mentioning she thought he might be present since he lived nearby.
She briefly held his hand while listening to two girls in identical yellow dresses who approached.
The girls greeted Jordan, offering commiserations for her recent loss in a golf tournament final.
One girl mentioned they had met Jordan at a previous party about a month ago.
Jordan observed that the girl had changed her hair color since then.
As the girls departed, Jordan linked her arm with Nick's, and they walked down into the garden.
They accepted cocktails from a passing tray and sat at a table with the two girls in yellow and three unnamed men.
Jordan asked one of the girls if she attended Gatsby's parties frequently.
The girl confirmed she attended the last one where they met.
Her companion, Lucille, added that she enjoyed the parties because she could act freely and always had fun.
Lucille recounted tearing her dress at a previous party and receiving a replacement gown from Gatsby worth $265 after he asked for her details.
Jordan inquired if Lucille kept the expensive gown, which Lucille confirmed, noting it needed alterations.
The other girl remarked on the peculiarity of Gatsby's generosity, suggesting he avoids confrontation.
When Nick asked who they were discussing, the name 'Gatsby' was mentioned.
The two girls and Jordan leaned in together conspiratorially.
One girl whispered a rumor that Gatsby had killed someone.
This rumor created a palpable thrill among the group, including the three men.
Lucille countered sceptically, suggesting it was more likely he was a German spy during the war.
One of the men claimed confirmation from someone who supposedly grew up with Gatsby in Germany.
The first girl dismissed the spy theory, pointing out Gatsby served in the American army.
She intensified the murder rumor, suggesting observing Gatsby when he thinks he's unnoticed reveals his guilt.
Both Lucille and the first girl shivered, and the group instinctively looked around for Gatsby.
Nick mused on the romantic speculation surrounding Gatsby, noting even those usually indiscreet whispered about him.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

events.text_segment:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.
Welcome or not, I found it necessary to attach myself to someone before I should begin to address cordial remarks to the passersby.
“Hello!” I roared, advancing toward her. My voice seemed unnaturally loud across the garden.
“I thought you might be here,” she responded absently as I came up. “I remembered you lived next door to—”
She held my hand impersonally, as a promise that she’d take care of me in a minute, and gave ear to two girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps.
“Hello!” they cried together. “Sorry you didn’t win.”
That was for the golf tournament. She had lost in the finals the week before.
“You don’t know who we are,” said one of the girls in yellow, “but we met you here about a month ago.”
“You’ve dyed your hair since then,” remarked Jordan, and I started, but the girls had moved casually on and her remark was addressed to the premature moon, produced like the supper, no doubt, out of a caterer’s basket. With Jordan’s slender golden arm resting in mine, we descended the steps and sauntered about the garden. A tray of cocktails floated at us through the twilight, and we sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each one introduced to us as Mr. Mumble.
“Do you come to these parties often?” inquired Jordan of the girl beside her.
“The last one was the one I met you at,” answered the girl, in an alert confident voice. She turned to her companion: “Wasn’t it for you, Lucille?”
It was for Lucille, too.
“I like to come,” Lucille said. “I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it.”
“Did you keep it?” asked Jordan.
“Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars.”
“There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that,” said the other girl eagerly. “He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody.”
“Who doesn’t?” I inquired.
“Gatsby. Somebody told me—”
The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.
“Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.”
A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.
“I don’t think it’s so much that,” argued Lucille sceptically; “It’s more that he was a German spy during the war.”
One of the men nodded in confirmation.
“I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany,” he assured us positively.
“Oh, no,” said the first girl, “it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war.” As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. “You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man.”
She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who had found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.

Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a courteous, soft speech. “I’ll rejoin you later.” When he was gone I turned immediately to Jordan—constrained to assure her of my surprise. I had expected that Mr. Gatsby would be a florid and corpulent person in his middle years.

“Who is he?” I demanded. “Do you know?”

“He’s just a man named Gatsby.”

“Where is he from, I mean? And what does he do?”

“Now you’re started on the subject,” she answered with a wan smile. “Well,—he told me once he was an Oxford man.”

A dim background started to take shape behind him but at her next remark it faded away.

“However, I don’t believe it.”

“Why not?”

“I don’t know,” she insisted, “I just don’t think he went there.”

Something in her tone reminded me of the other girls I had heard that evening, who were now clustered in the garden, talking with Jordan and me. Two girls in twin yellow dresses stopped at the foot of the steps.

“Hello!” they cried together. “Sorry you didn’t win.”

That was for Jordan, who lifted her chin and answered, “You don’t know who won.”

“We don’t care,” said one of the girls in yellow, and they laughed.

“Are you having a good time?”

“Lots of fun.”

“Who’s your friend?”

“Mr. Carraway. Mr. Carraway, this is Lucille.”

Another girl, who had changed her dress since we last met, nodded at me. “I met you here last month.”

“I remember. You had your hair bobbed then.”

“Yes, I changed it. Isn’t it lovely?”

They all sat down at a table with us, and a tray of cocktails floated by. We took drinks and settled in. Lucille leaned forward confidentially.

“I like to come,” Lucille said. “I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it. Did you keep it?”

“Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars.”

“There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that,” said the other girl eagerly. “He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody.”

“Who doesn’t?” I inquired.

“Gatsby. Somebody told me—”

The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.

“Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once.”

A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.

“I don’t think it’s so much that,” argued Lucille skeptically; “it’s more that he was a German spy during the war.”

One of the men nodded in confirmation.

“I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany.”

“Oh, no,” said the first girl, “it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war.”

As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. “You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man.”

She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.
