simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
I was on my way to get roaring drunk from sheer embarrassment when Jordan Baker came out of the house and stood at the head of the marble steps, leaning a little backward and looking with contemptuous interest down into the garden.

Almost immediately the two girls in twin yellow dresses, who had stopped at the foot of the steps, came up to Jordan and me and introduced themselves. They were both in yellow and their hair was bobbed in the same way. The younger of the two addressed Jordan:

"Hello!" she cried. "Sorry you didn’t win."

Jordan lifted her chin and answered, "You don’t know who won."

"Oh, we don’t care," said the other girl in yellow. "But if you’ll excuse me, I thought you might be here."

She held my hand impersonally, as a promise that she’d take care of me in a minute, and gave ear to two girls in twin yellow dresses, who stopped at the foot of the steps.

"Hello!" they cried together. "Sorry you didn’t win."

That was for Jordan, who lifted her chin and answered, "You don’t know who won."

"We don’t care," said one of the girls in yellow, and they laughed.

"Are you having a good time?"

"Lots of fun."

"Who’s your friend?"

"Mr. Carraway. Mr. Carraway, this is Lucille."

The other girl, who had changed her dress since we last met, nodded at me. "I met you here last month."

"I remember. You had your hair bobbed then."

"Yes, I changed it. Isn’t it lovely?"

They descended the steps together, Jordan and I arm in arm, and a tray of cocktails floated at us through the twilight. We sat down at a table with the two girls in yellow and three men, each one introduced to us as Mr. Mumble.

"Do you come to these parties often?" inquired Jordan of the girl beside her.

"The last one was the one I met you at," answered the girl in yellow, turning to her companion. "Don’t you remember?"

"I do, but I don’t think I’ve seen you before."

"You must know Gatsby."

"Gatsby?" demanded Daisy. "What Gatsby?"

"Why, Gatsby."

Lucille leaned forward confidentially. "I like to come," Lucille said. "I never care what I do, so I always have a good time. When I was here last I tore my gown on a chair, and he asked me my name and address—inside of a week I got a package from Croirier’s with a new evening gown in it. Did you keep it?"

"Sure I did. I was going to wear it tonight, but it was too big in the bust and had to be altered. It was gas blue with lavender beads. Two hundred and sixty-five dollars."

"There’s something funny about a fellow that’ll do a thing like that," said the other girl eagerly. "He doesn’t want any trouble with anybody."

"Who doesn’t?" I inquired.

"Gatsby. Somebody told me—"

The two girls and Jordan leaned together confidentially.

"Somebody told me they thought he killed a man once."

A thrill passed over all of us. The three Mr. Mumbles bent forward and listened eagerly.

"I don’t think it’s so much that," argued Lucille skeptically; "it’s more that he was a German spy during the war."

One of the men nodded in confirmation.

"I heard that from a man who knew all about him, grew up with him in Germany."

"Oh, no," said the first girl, "it couldn’t be that, because he was in the American army during the war."

As our credulity switched back to her she leaned forward with enthusiasm. "You look at him sometimes when he thinks nobody’s looking at him. I’ll bet he killed a man."

She narrowed her eyes and shivered. Lucille shivered. We all turned and looked around for Gatsby. It was testimony to the romantic speculation he inspired that there were whispers about him from those who found little that it was necessary to whisper about in this world.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I paused, uncertain whether to approach her or to slip away into the shadows. The moonlight caught the edge of her dress, making her seem almost ethereal, a figure carved from the pale stone of the steps themselves. She glanced at me, her eyes cool and appraising, and for a moment I felt as though she could see straight through me, to the awkwardness and confusion that churned beneath my surface.

"You look as if you could use a drink," she said, her voice low and amused. I managed a weak smile and nodded, grateful for the excuse to move, to do something other than stand there feeling exposed. Together, we walked back toward the house, the sounds of laughter and music growing louder as we approached the open French windows.

Inside, the party had swelled to a fever pitch. The orchestra played a wild, jazzy tune, and couples spun across the floor in a blur of color and movement. Waiters darted through the crowd with trays of cocktails, and everywhere there was the clink of glasses, the murmur of voices, the occasional burst of raucous laughter. I felt out of place, as though I had stumbled into a world that was not my own, a world of effortless glamour and careless extravagance.

Jordan led me to a small table near the edge of the dance floor, where we sat and watched the revelers swirl past. She seemed perfectly at ease, her posture relaxed, her gaze detached but not unkind. I envied her composure, her ability to float above the chaos without being swept away by it.

"Do you come to these parties often?" I asked, trying to make conversation.

She shrugged. "I've been to a few. Gatsby's parties are famous, you know. People come from all over just to see what they're like. Half the time, they don't even know him."

I glanced around, realizing that she was right. The guests seemed to move in their own orbits, rarely interacting with their host, who remained a mysterious presence somewhere in the background. I wondered what it must be like to throw such lavish parties for people who barely knew you, to watch them enjoy your hospitality without ever truly being a part of it.

As if reading my thoughts, Jordan leaned in and said, "No one really knows Gatsby. He's a mystery, even to the people who claim to be his friends. There are all sorts of stories about him—some say he was a German spy during the war, others that he killed a man."

I laughed, surprised by the absurdity of the rumors. "Do you believe any of that?"

She smiled, a hint of mischief in her eyes. "I don't know what to believe. But I do know that people will say anything when they're bored."

We sat in companionable silence for a moment, watching the party unfold around us. I felt a strange sense of detachment, as though I were observing the scene from a great distance, removed from the noise and excitement. It occurred to me that this was the essence of Gatsby's world—a place where appearances mattered more than reality, where everyone wore a mask and no one dared to look too closely beneath the surface.

As the night wore on, the party showed no signs of slowing down. The music grew louder, the dancing more frenetic, and the air was thick with the scent of perfume and champagne. I found myself drawn into the rhythm of the evening, swept along by the current of energy that pulsed through the room. For a little while, I forgot my embarrassment, lost in the glittering world that Gatsby had created.

events.title: Encounter with the Owl-Eyed Man in the Library
detailed_summary: As the first supper service began, Jordan invited Nick to join her group at another table.
This group consisted of three married couples and Jordan's persistent, suggestive undergraduate escort, representing East Egg's reserved nobility contrasting with West Egg's flamboyance.
After about thirty minutes, Jordan expressed boredom with the polite company and suggested they leave to find Gatsby, noting Nick's unease about not having met him.
They searched the crowded bar, the top of the steps, and the veranda without finding Gatsby.
They decided to try an imposing door and entered a grand, oak-panelled library, likely imported.
Inside, a stout, middle-aged man with large spectacles sat drunk on a table, staring intently at the bookshelves.
He turned excitedly upon their entrance and scrutinized Jordan.
He demanded their opinion about the books.
Waving towards the shelves, he declared he had already ascertained their authenticity – they were real books with pages.
He expressed surprise, having expected them to be convincing fakes, like cardboard props.
To prove his point, he fetched a volume of the 'Stoddard Lectures'.
He triumphantly presented it as genuine printed matter, comparing Gatsby to the theatrical producer Belasco for his thorough realism.
He noted the pages weren't cut, implying they hadn't been read, but still praised the effort.
He quickly returned the book, warning that removing one might cause the whole library facade to collapse.
He inquired if Nick and Jordan were brought by someone, stating most guests were, including himself.
He mentioned being brought by a Mrs. Claud Roosevelt whom he met the previous night.
He admitted he'd been drunk for a week and hoped sitting in the library would sober him up.
When asked if it worked, he was unsure, having only been there an hour, and started to talk about the real books again.
Nick and Jordan confirmed he'd already told them, shook his hand formally, and left the library.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.

events.text_segment:
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo, and obviously under the impression that sooner or later Jordan was going to yield him up her person to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of rambling, this party had preserved a dignified homogeneity, and assumed to itself the function of representing the staid nobility of the countryside—East Egg condescending to West Egg and carefully on guard against its spectroscopic gaiety.
“Let’s get out,” whispered Jordan, after a somehow wasteful and inappropriate half-hour; “this is much too polite for me.”
We got up, and she explained that we were going to find the host: I had never met him, she said, and it was making me uneasy. The undergraduate nodded in a cynical, melancholy way.
The bar, where we glanced first, was crowded, but Gatsby was not there. She couldn’t find him from the top of the steps, and he wasn’t on the veranda. On a chance we tried an important-looking door, and walked into a high Gothic library, panelled with carved English oak, and probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.
A stout, middle-aged man, with enormous owl-eyed spectacles, was sitting somewhat drunk on the edge of a great table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. As we entered he wheeled excitedly around and examined Jordan from head to foot.
“What do you think?” he demanded impetuously.
“About what?”
He waved his hand toward the bookshelves.
“About that. As a matter of fact you needn’t bother to ascertain. I ascertained. They’re real.”
“The books?”
He nodded.
“Absolutely real—have pages and everything. I thought they’d be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they’re absolutely real. Pages and—Here! Lemme show you.”
Taking our scepticism for granted, he rushed to the bookcases and returned with Volume One of the Stoddard Lectures.
“See!” he cried triumphantly. “It’s a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?”
He snatched the book from me and replaced it hastily on its shelf, muttering that if one brick was removed the whole library was liable to collapse.
“Who brought you?” he demanded. “Or did you just come? I was brought. Most people were brought.”
Jordan looked at him alertly, cheerfully, without answering.
“I was brought by a woman named Roosevelt,” he continued. “Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? I met her somewhere last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.”
“Has it?”
“A little bit, I think. I can’t tell yet. I’ve only been here an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They’re real. They’re—”
“You told us.”
We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
The first supper—there would be another one after midnight—was now being served, and Jordan invited me to join her own party, who were spread around a table on the other side of the garden. There were three married couples and Jordan’s escort, a persistent undergraduate given to violent innuendo, and obviously under the impression that sooner or later Jordan was going to yield him up her person to a greater or lesser degree. Instead of rambling, this party had preserved a dignified homogeneity, and assumed to itself the function of representing the staid nobility of the countryside—East Egg condescending to West Egg, and carefully on guard against its spectroscopic gayety.

“Let’s get out,” whispered Jordan, after a somehow wasteful and inappropriate half hour. “This is much too polite for me.”

We got up, and she explained that we were going to find the host: I had never met him, she said, and it was necessary for me to do so. “Let’s look for him in the bar,” she suggested. “He can’t be in the garden, or they’d know him.”

We passed through the bar, from the garden to the house, and found the bar crowded with people. We passed a curtain, and found ourselves in a high hallway, with a stairway leading up to the top of the house. We searched for Gatsby in the bar, on the stairs, and in the veranda, but he was not to be found. At last we came upon a door which Jordan opened cautiously, and we entered a high Gothic library, paneled with carved English oak, and probably transported complete from some ruin overseas.

A stout, middle-aged man, with enormous owl-eyed spectacles, was sitting somewhat drunk on the edge of a great table, staring with unsteady concentration at the shelves of books. As we entered he wheeled excitedly around and examined Jordan from head to foot.

“What do you think?” he demanded impetuously.

“About what?”

He waved his hand toward the book-shelves.

“About that. As a matter of fact you needn’t bother to ascertain. I ascertained. They’re real.”

“The books?”

He nodded.

“Absolutely real—have pages and everything. I thought they’d be a nice durable cardboard. Matter of fact, they’re absolutely real. Pages and—Here! Lemme show you.”

Taking our skepticism for granted, he rushed to the bookcases and returned with Volume One of the “Stoddard Lectures.”

“See!” he cried triumphantly. “It’s a bona-fide piece of printed matter. It fooled me. This fella’s a regular Belasco. It’s a triumph. What thoroughness! What realism! Knew when to stop, too—didn’t cut the pages. But what do you want? What do you expect?”

He snatched the book from me and replaced it hastily on its shelf, muttering that if one brick was removed the whole library was liable to collapse.

“Who brought you?” he demanded. “Or did you just come? I was brought. Most people were brought.”

Jordan looked at him alertly, cheerfully, without answering.

“I was brought by a woman named Roosevelt,” he continued. “Mrs. Claud Roosevelt. Do you know her? I met her somewhere last night. I’ve been drunk for about a week now, and I thought it might sober me up to sit in a library.”

“Has it?”

“A little bit, I think. I can’t tell yet. I’ve only been here an hour. Did I tell you about the books? They’re real. They’re——”

“You told us.”

We shook hands with him gravely and went back outdoors.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I found her sitting with two girls in yellow and a man who, with a sort of jealous curiosity, looked at me as though he had heard some story about me before. The two girls in yellow, who were twins, turned to me with identical, impersonal smiles, and Jordan introduced me as “Nick.”

“We’re all here for Gatsby,” one of the twins said, raising her glass. “He throws the most wonderful parties.”

The table was crowded with plates of hors d’oeuvres, bowls of salad, and bottles of champagne. The laughter and chatter from the other tables drifted over to us, mingling with the strains of the orchestra, which had begun to play a lively tune. The garden was illuminated by hundreds of lanterns, casting a soft glow over the guests, who seemed to float through the night in their bright dresses and dark suits.

Jordan leaned toward me, her eyes sparkling. “Have you met Gatsby yet?” she asked.

I shook my head. “I haven’t even seen him. Has anyone?”

The man beside me, who had been listening intently, spoke up. “I was brought by a friend. I haven’t seen him either. They say he’s always around, but no one knows where.”

One of the twins giggled. “I heard he once killed a man.”

Her sister nodded solemnly. “He was a German spy during the war.”

Jordan laughed. “Oh, please. I heard he was an Oxford man.”

The man beside me shrugged. “I heard he’s a nephew or a cousin of Kaiser Wilhelm. That’s where all his money comes from.”

The conversation drifted from rumor to rumor, each more fantastic than the last. I listened, fascinated by the way Gatsby’s guests constructed his legend, each adding a new detail to the mystery. The orchestra played on, and the party grew louder, more exuberant.

After a while, Jordan suggested we explore the grounds. We left the table and wandered through the garden, past groups of laughing guests and waiters balancing trays of drinks. The house loomed above us, its windows glowing with light. We passed a group of young men and women gathered around a table, deep in conversation, and a couple dancing alone on the lawn.

As we walked, Jordan told me about her golf career and the tournaments she had played in. She spoke with a casual confidence, as if she were used to being admired. I found myself drawn to her, intrigued by her poise and self-assurance.

We made our way back to the house, where the music was louder and the crowd thicker. Inside, the rooms were filled with guests, some dancing, others talking in small groups. The air was heavy with the scent of flowers and perfume.

Suddenly, Jordan stopped and pointed across the room. “There he is,” she said. “That’s Gatsby.”

I followed her gaze and saw a man standing alone on the steps, watching the party with a faint, enigmatic smile. He was handsome, with tanned skin and short, neatly cut hair. He looked both young and somehow weary, as if he had seen too much of the world.

Jordan took my arm and led me toward him. As we approached, Gatsby turned and greeted us with a polite nod. His voice was soft and courteous, and there was something in his manner that set him apart from the other guests—a sense of purpose, of quiet intensity.

For a moment, we stood together, the three of us, surrounded by the noise and excitement of the party. And in that moment, I felt as if I had stepped into a world of possibility, a world where anything could happen.

events.title: Nick Unknowingly Meets Gatsby
detailed_summary: Back outside, dancing had commenced on the garden's canvas platform.
Various couples danced, some awkwardly, some fashionably, while single girls danced alone or briefly joined the orchestra.
By midnight, the party's energy escalated; performers sang, guests performed 'stunts,' and laughter filled the air.
The girls in yellow performed a costumed act, and champagne was served in large glasses.
The moon cast a silvery light on the Sound.
Nick, still with Jordan, sat at a table with a man his age and a boisterous young woman.
Nick began enjoying himself after drinking champagne, finding the scene transformed.
During a pause, the man at the table smiled at Nick.
The man commented on Nick's familiar face and asked if he served in the First Division during the war.
Nick confirmed his service in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.
The man shared his own service in the Sixteenth Infantry.
They briefly reminisced about villages in France.
The man mentioned living nearby, having just bought a hydroplane he planned to test.
He invited Nick to join him for a flight along the shore the next morning.
Nick agreed and asked for a time, receiving a flexible response.
Just as Nick was about to ask the man's name, Jordan interjected, asking if he was having a better time.
Nick confirmed he was enjoying himself more and turned back to the man.
He explained the party was unusual for him as he hadn't met the host, gesturing towards his own house nearby and mentioning Gatsby sent the invitation.
The man looked momentarily confused.
He then identified himself suddenly as Gatsby.
Nick expressed surprise and apologized.
Gatsby, calling Nick 'old sport,' apologized for being a poor host, assuming Nick already knew who he was.
Gatsby offered a remarkable, reassuring smile that seemed to embrace the world before focusing entirely on Nick with immense favor.
The smile conveyed deep understanding and belief, projecting the exact positive impression Nick hoped to make.
The smile vanished abruptly, revealing an elegant man around thirty, whose formal speech bordered on absurd, suggesting carefully chosen words.
Nick realized Gatsby had been selecting his words deliberately even before the introduction.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.

events.text_segment:
There was dancing now on the canvas in the garden; old men pushing young girls backward in eternal graceless circles, superior couples holding each other tortuously, fashionably, and keeping in the corners—and a great number of single girls dancing individually or relieving the orchestra for a moment of the burden of the banjo or the traps. By midnight the hilarity had increased. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing “stunts” all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. A pair of stage twins, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, did a baby act in costume, and champagne was served in glasses bigger than finger-bowls. The moon had risen higher, and floating in the Sound was a triangle of silver scales, trembling a little to the stiff, tinny drip of the banjoes on the lawn.
I was still with Jordan Baker. We were sitting at a table with a man of about my age and a rowdy little girl, who gave way upon the slightest provocation to uncontrollable laughter. I was enjoying myself now. I had taken two finger-bowls of champagne, and the scene had changed before my eyes into something significant, elemental, and profound.
At a lull in the entertainment the man looked at me and smiled.
“Your face is familiar,” he said politely. “Weren’t you in the First Division during the war?”
“Why yes. I was in the Twenty-eighth Infantry.”
“I was in the Sixteenth until June nineteen-eighteen. I knew I’d seen you somewhere before.”
We talked for a moment about some wet, grey little villages in France. Evidently he lived in this vicinity, for he told me that he had just bought a hydroplane, and was going to try it out in the morning.
“Want to go with me, old sport? Just near the shore along the Sound.”
“What time?”
“Any time that suits you best.”
It was on the tip of my tongue to ask his name when Jordan looked around and smiled.
“Having a gay time now?” she inquired.
“Much better.” I turned again to my new acquaintance. “This is an unusual party for me. I haven’t even seen the host. I live over there—” I waved my hand at the invisible hedge in the distance, “and this man Gatsby sent over his chauffeur with an invitation.”
For a moment he looked at me as if he failed to understand.
“I’m Gatsby,” he said suddenly.
“What!” I exclaimed. “Oh, I beg your pardon.”
“I thought you knew, old sport. I’m afraid I’m not a very good host.”
He smiled understandingly—much more than understandingly. It was one of those rare smiles with a quality of eternal reassurance in it, that you may come across four or five times in life. It faced—or seemed to face—the whole eternal world for an instant, and then concentrated on you with an irresistible prejudice in your favour. It understood you just so far as you wanted to be understood, believed in you as you would like to believe in yourself, and assured you that it had precisely the impression of you that, at your best, you hoped to convey. Precisely at that point it vanished—and I was looking at an elegant young roughneck, a year or two over thirty, whose elaborate formality of speech just missed being absurd. Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
By midnight the hilarity had increased. A celebrated tenor had sung in Italian, and a notorious contralto had sung in jazz, and between the numbers people were doing "stunts" all over the garden, while happy, vacuous bursts of laughter rose toward the summer sky. A pair of stage twins, who turned out to be the girls in yellow, did a baby act in costume, and champagne was served in glasses bigger than finger bowls.

The moon had risen higher, and floating in the Sound was a triangle of silver scales, trembling a little to the stiff, tinny drip of the banjoes on the lawn. Inside, the crimson room bloomed with light. The bar is in full swing, and floating rounds of cocktails permeate the garden outside, until the air is alive with chatter and laughter and casual innuendo and introductions forgotten on the spot, and enthusiastic meetings between women who never knew each other's names.

The lights grow brighter as the earth lurches away from the sun, and now the orchestra is playing yellow cocktail music, and the opera of voices pitches a key higher. Laughter is easier, minute by minute, spilled with prodigality, tipped out at a cheerful word. The groups change more swiftly, swell with new arrivals, dissolve and form in the same breath; already there are wanderers, confident girls who weave here and there among the stouter and more stable, become for a sharp, joyous moment the center of a group, and then, excited with triumph, glide on through the sea-change of faces and voices and color under the constantly changing light.

Suddenly one of the gypsies, in trembling opal, seizes a cocktail out of the air, dumps it down for courage and, moving her hands like Frisco, dances out alone on the canvas platform. A momentary hush; the orchestra leader varies his rhythm obligingly for her, and there is a burst of chatter as the erroneous news goes around that she is Gilda Gray's understudy from the Follies. The party has begun.

I believe that on the first night I went to Gatsby's house I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were not invited—they went there. They got into automobiles which bore them out to Long Island, and somehow they ended up at Gatsby's door. Once there they were introduced by somebody who knew Gatsby, and after that they conducted themselves according to the rules of behavior associated with amusement parks. Sometimes they came and went without having met Gatsby at all, came for the party with a simplicity of heart that was its own ticket of admission.

I had been actually invited. A chauffeur in a uniform of robin's-egg blue crossed my lawn early that Saturday morning with a surprisingly formal note from his employer: the honor would be entirely Gatsby's, it said, if I would attend his "little party" that night. He had seen me several times, and had intended to call on me long before, but a peculiar combination of circumstances had prevented it—signed Jay Gatsby, in a majestic hand.

events.title: Gatsby's Enigma and Detachment
detailed_summary: Immediately after Gatsby identified himself, a butler arrived with news of a phone call from Chicago.
Gatsby excused himself courteously to the group, urging Nick to ask for anything he needed and promising to return later.
Once Gatsby left, Nick turned to Jordan, expressing his surprise, admitting he had pictured Gatsby as older and heavier.
Nick asked Jordan about Gatsby's identity and origins.
Jordan replied simply that he's 'just a man named Gatsby.'
When pressed about Gatsby's background and profession, Jordan mentioned Gatsby once claimed to be an Oxford graduate.
This briefly created a potential background for Gatsby, but Jordan immediately expressed her disbelief.
Her sceptical tone reminded Nick of the earlier rumor about Gatsby killing someone, fueling his curiosity.
Nick reflected that humble origins would be understandable, but a young man mysteriously appearing and buying a palace seemed implausible.
Jordan steered the conversation away from specifics, stating she likes Gatsby's large, intimate parties where privacy is possible.
The orchestra leader announced the next piece, requested by Gatsby: Vladimir Tostoff's 'Jazz History of the World,' described as a recent sensation.
As the music started, Nick observed Gatsby standing alone on the steps, watching the party with an approving gaze.
Nick noted Gatsby's healthy appearance and neat grooming, seeing nothing sinister.
He speculated Gatsby's sobriety might set him apart, as Gatsby seemed to grow more formal while the guests became more uninhibited.
After the music ended, guests engaged in playful, intimate behavior, but no one approached Gatsby in such a manner; he remained separate.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that someone would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.

events.text_segment:
Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a small bow that included each of us in turn.
“If you want anything just ask for it, old sport,” he urged me. “Excuse me. I will rejoin you later.”
When he was gone I turned immediately to Jordan—constrained to assure her of my surprise. I had expected that Mr. Gatsby would be a florid and corpulent person in his middle years.
“Who is he?” I demanded. “Do you know?”
“He’s just a man named Gatsby.”
“Where is he from, I mean? And what does he do?”
“Now you’re started on the subject,” she answered with a wan smile. “Well, he told me once he was an Oxford man.”
A dim background started to take shape behind him, but at her next remark it faded away.
“However, I don’t believe it.”
“Why not?”
“I don’t know,” she insisted, “I just don’t think he went there.”
Something in her tone reminded me of the other girl’s “I think he killed a man,” and had the effect of stimulating my curiosity. I would have accepted without question the information that Gatsby sprang from the swamps of Louisiana or from the lower East Side of New York. That was comprehensible. But young men didn’t—at least in my provincial inexperience I believed they didn’t—drift coolly out of nowhere and buy a palace on Long Island Sound.
“Anyhow, he gives large parties,” said Jordan, changing the subject with an urban distaste for the concrete. “And I like large parties. They’re so intimate. At small parties there isn’t any privacy.”
There was the boom of a bass drum, and the voice of the orchestra leader rang out suddenly above the echolalia of the garden.
“Ladies and gentlemen,” he cried. “At the request of Mr. Gatsby we are going to play for you Mr. Vladmir Tostoff’s latest work, which attracted so much attention at Carnegie Hall last May. If you read the papers you know there was a big sensation.” He smiled with jovial condescension, and added: “Some sensation!” Whereupon everybody laughed.
“The piece is known,” he concluded lustily, “as ‘Vladmir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World!’ ”
The nature of Mr. Tostoff’s composition eluded me, because just as it began my eyes fell on Gatsby, standing alone on the marble steps and looking from one group to another with approving eyes. His tanned skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests, for it seemed to me that he grew more correct as the fraternal hilarity increased. When the “Jazz History of the World” was over, girls were putting their heads on men’s shoulders in a puppyish, convivial way, girls were swooning backward playfully into men’s arms, even into groups, knowing that someone would arrest their falls—but no one swooned backward on Gatsby, and no French bob touched Gatsby’s shoulder, and no singing quartets were formed with Gatsby’s head for one link.

Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself a butler hurried toward him with the information that Chicago was calling him on the wire. He excused himself with a courteous, brief nod and disappeared. Jordan and I tried to keep up the conversation, but it was difficult. I felt a little shocked at the elaborateness of the lie. When I had first met him I had been so taken aback that I had forgotten to ask him the one question that was on my mind: “Who is he, anyhow, an actor?”

“No.”

“A bootlegger?”

“One time he killed a man who had found out that he was nephew to Von Hindenburg and second cousin to the devil.”

“Come on, Jordan. They’re just rumors.”

She smiled. “Well, he told me once he was an Oxford man.”

A dim background started to take shape behind him, but at her next remark it faded away.

“However, I don’t believe it.”

“Why not?”

“I don’t know,” she insisted, “I just don’t think he went there.”

Something in her tone reminded me of the other girls I had found at Gatsby’s party, who had whispered that he was a German spy during the war. I immediately looked around for Gatsby, but he was nowhere to be seen. I was about to ask Jordan to explain further when the orchestra leader announced a new piece, requested by Mr. Gatsby: Vladimir Tostoff’s Jazz History of the World. The piece had been causing a sensation in New York, and as the music started, I saw Gatsby standing alone on the marble steps and looking from one group to another with approving eyes. His tanned skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests, for it seemed to me that he grew more correct as the fraternal hilarity increased. 1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- Early in the passage, the completion invents a conversation about Gatsby being an actor, a bootlegger, and a murderer, which does not occur in the original at this point. This invented dialogue replaces the actual exchange between the narrator and Jordan about Gatsby's background and rumors.
- The completion omits the narrator's immediate reaction to Gatsby's departure and the specific way he turns to Jordan to express his surprise and expectations about Gatsby's appearance.
- The completion introduces invented references to other girls at the party and rumors about Gatsby being a German spy, which are not present in this section of the original.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion skips the narrator's internal reflection about his preconceived notions regarding Gatsby's origins and the improbability of someone like Gatsby acquiring a mansion on Long Island.
- The transition in the conversation, where Jordan changes the subject to Gatsby's parties and her opinion about large versus small parties, is missing. This shift is important for the flow and thematic development.
- The specific details of the orchestra leader's announcement, including the context and the audience's reaction, are condensed and lack the full sequence of events and dialogue present in the original.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion inaccurately attributes invented dialogue and rumors to the narrator and Jordan, which alters the tone and content of their exchange.
- The sequence of events is disrupted by the insertion of invented conversations and by omitting the narrator's direct questions and Jordan's responses about Gatsby's background.
- The description of the orchestra leader's announcement is generalized and does not accurately reflect the order and content of the original announcement and audience reaction.
- The completion maintains some accurate descriptive details about Gatsby's appearance and the party's atmosphere, but the lead-up to these observations is altered by the preceding invented and missing content.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He excused himself with a courteous nod, his smile lingering for a moment before he turned away, disappearing into the crowd with the same effortless grace that seemed to define his every movement. The party continued around me, the laughter and music swelling as if to fill the space he had left behind. I found myself standing alone, clutching my empty glass, uncertain whether to follow him or remain where I was.

The guests, oblivious to Gatsby’s sudden departure, drifted from group to group, their conversations punctuated by bursts of merriment and the clinking of crystal. I watched as a pair of young women, their dresses shimmering in the light, leaned in close to whisper, their eyes darting toward the door through which Gatsby had vanished. Rumors, I realized, were as much a part of these gatherings as the champagne and the orchestra.

I wandered through the garden, the night air heavy with the scent of roses and the distant hum of automobiles arriving and departing. The moon hung low over the bay, casting a silver path across the water toward the mysterious green light that marked the end of Daisy Buchanan’s dock. I paused for a moment, gazing at that light, wondering what it meant to Gatsby, and what it might come to mean to me.

Inside, the party showed no signs of abating. The orchestra launched into a new tune, the tempo quickening as couples took to the dance floor. I caught sight of Jordan Baker, her cool, self-possessed manner undisturbed by the revelry around her. She raised an eyebrow as I approached, a faint smile playing at the corners of her mouth.

“Enjoying yourself?” she asked, her tone light but her eyes searching.

“I suppose so,” I replied. “It’s all rather overwhelming.”

She laughed softly. “You get used to it. Or you don’t. Gatsby throws these parties every weekend, but I don’t think he enjoys them any more than you do.”

I glanced back toward the house, half-expecting to see Gatsby reappear. “He seems very… reserved.”

Jordan nodded. “He’s a peculiar man. There’s a lot of talk about him, but no one really knows the truth.”

Before I could respond, a commotion near the bar drew our attention. A man in a white dinner jacket was gesticulating wildly, insisting that he had just seen a famous movie star in the crowd. The guests surged in that direction, eager for a glimpse of celebrity, their curiosity as insatiable as ever.

Jordan and I lingered at the edge of the terrace, watching the scene unfold. The night seemed to stretch on endlessly, the boundaries between reality and illusion blurring in the golden glow of Gatsby’s lanterns. I felt a strange sense of anticipation, as if something momentous were about to happen, though I could not have said what it was.

At last, Gatsby returned, his expression composed but his eyes betraying a hint of distraction. He apologized for his absence, and the conversation resumed, but I sensed that the call from Chicago had unsettled him. The party continued, but for me, the evening had taken on a new and mysterious significance.

events.title: Gatsby Summons Jordan; Party Degenerates
detailed_summary: Gatsby's butler approached Nick and Jordan.
He requested Miss Baker speak with Mr. Gatsby privately.
Jordan reacted with surprise but slowly rose and followed the butler towards the house.
Nick observed Jordan's athletic posture and movement, likening her walk to one developed on golf courses.
Alone again near two a.m., Nick heard intriguing, confused sounds from a room overlooking the terrace.
Avoiding Jordan's former escort (now occupied with chorus girls), Nick went inside the room.
The large room was crowded.
One of the girls in yellow played piano while a red-haired chorus singer performed.
The singer, heavily intoxicated with champagne, had become overwhelmed with sadness, weeping as she sang.
She filled pauses with sobs before continuing in a trembling voice, tears making black streaks through her makeup.
A guest humorously suggested she sing the tear tracks, causing her to collapse into a chair in a drunken sleep.
A nearby girl explained to Nick that the singer had argued with her supposed husband.
Nick looked around and noticed many women arguing with men presumed to be their husbands.
Even Jordan's sophisticated East Egg group had descended into discord; one man focused intently on an actress while his wife alternated between feigned indifference and angry, whispered accusations.
Resistance to leaving wasn't limited to men; two sober men were being urged to leave by their indignant wives.
The wives complained loudly to each other about their husbands wanting to leave whenever they were having fun, calling it selfish.
One husband pointed out sheepishly that they were nearly the last guests, as the orchestra had already left.
Despite the wives' agreement on the husbands' unbelievable behavior, the argument ended with the men physically carrying their protesting wives out.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “I beg your pardon.”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

events.text_segment:
“I beg your pardon.”
Gatsby’s butler was suddenly standing beside us.
“Miss Baker?” he inquired. “I beg your pardon, but Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you alone.”
“With me?” she exclaimed in surprise.
“Yes, madame.”
She got up slowly, raising her eyebrows at me in astonishment, and followed the butler toward the house. I noticed that she wore her evening-dress, all her dresses, like sports clothes—there was a jauntiness about her movements as if she had first learned to walk upon golf courses on clean, crisp mornings.
I was alone and it was almost two. For some time confused and intriguing sounds had issued from a long, many-windowed room which overhung the terrace. Eluding Jordan’s undergraduate, who was now engaged in an obstetrical conversation with two chorus girls, and who implored me to join him, I went inside.
The large room was full of people. One of the girls in yellow was playing the piano, and beside her stood a tall, red-haired young lady from a famous chorus, engaged in song. She had drunk a quantity of champagne, and during the course of her song she had decided, ineptly, that everything was very, very sad—she was not only singing, she was weeping too. Whenever there was a pause in the song she filled it with gasping, broken sobs, and then took up the lyric again in a quavering soprano. The tears coursed down her cheeks—not freely, however, for when they came into contact with her heavily beaded eyelashes they assumed an inky colour, and pursued the rest of their way in slow black rivulets. A humorous suggestion was made that she sing the notes on her face, whereupon she threw up her hands, sank into a chair, and went off into a deep vinous sleep.
“She had a fight with a man who says he’s her husband,” explained a girl at my elbow.
I looked around. Most of the remaining women were now having fights with men said to be their husbands. Even Jordan’s party, the quartet from East Egg, were rent asunder by dissension. One of the men was talking with curious intensity to a young actress, and his wife, after attempting to laugh at the situation in a dignified and indifferent way, broke down entirely and resorted to flank attacks—at intervals she appeared suddenly at his side like an angry diamond, and hissed: “You promised!” into his ear.
The reluctance to go home was not confined to wayward men. The hall was at present occupied by two deplorably sober men and their highly indignant wives. The wives were sympathizing with each other in slightly raised voices.
“Whenever he sees I’m having a good time he wants to go home.”
“Never heard anything so selfish in my life.”
“We’re always the first ones to leave.”
“So are we.”
“Well, we’re almost the last tonight,” said one of the men sheepishly. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.”
In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

“I beg your pardon.”

Gatsby’s butler was suddenly standing beside us. “Miss Baker?” he inquired. “I beg your pardon, but Mr. Gatsby would like to speak to you alone.”

“With me?” she exclaimed in surprise.

“Yes, madame.”

She got up slowly, raising her eyebrows at me in astonishment, and followed the butler toward the house. I noticed that she wore her evening dress, all her movements were as if she were balancing something on her chin. She held her head so high that her posture gave her a certain athletic grace, as if she had just come off the golf course and was about to start again.

I was alone and it was almost two. For some time I sat on the marble steps, watching the confusion of men and women, who had tried to leave, but who had not yet gone. A little while later I heard a peculiar combination of confused sounds from the room behind me. I looked in. There was a large room, full of people. One of the girls in yellow was playing the piano, and beside her stood a tall, red-haired young lady from a chorus, engaged in song. She had drunk a quantity of champagne, and during the course of her song she had decided that everything was very, very sad—she was not only singing, she was weeping too. Whenever there was a pause in the song she filled it with gasping broken sobs, and then took up the lyric again in a quavering soprano. The tears coursed down her cheeks—not freely, however, for when they came into contact with her heavily beaded eyelashes they assumed an inky color, and pursued the rest of their way in slow black rivulets. A humorous suggestion was made that she sing the notes on her face, whereupon she threw up her hands, sank into a chair, and went off into a deep vinous sleep.

“She had a fight with a man who says he’s her husband,” explained a girl at my elbow.

I looked around. Most of the remaining women were now having fights with men said to be their husbands. Even Jordan’s party, the quartet from East Egg, were rent asunder by dissension. One of the men was talking with curious intensity to a young actress, and his wife, after attempting to laugh at the situation in a dignified and indifferent way, broke down entirely and resorted to flank attacks—at intervals she appeared suddenly at his side like an angry diamond, and hissed: “You promised!” into his ear.

The reluctance to go home was not confined to wayward men. The hall was at present occupied by two deplorably sober men and their highly indignant wives. The wives were sympathizing with each other in slightly raised voices.

“Whenever he sees I’m having a good time he wants to go home.”

“Never heard anything so selfish in my life.”

“We’re always the first ones to leave.”

So are we.”

“Well, we’re almost the last tonight,” said one of the men sheepishly. “The orchestra left half an hour ago.”

In spite of the wives’ agreement that such malevolence was beyond credibility, the dispute ended in a short struggle, and both wives were lifted, kicking, into the night.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.refinement_prompt:
IMPROVEMENT GUIDANCE:
1. MAJOR STRUCTURAL ISSUES:
- In the early part of the completion, there is an invented description of Jordan Baker's posture and movements that does not match the original passage. The completion adds details about her balancing something on her chin and holding her head high, which are not present in the source material.
- The completion omits the original's specific comparison of Jordan's manner of wearing her dresses and her movements to sports clothes and golf courses on crisp mornings. This is a significant descriptive element that sets the tone for her character in this scene.
- The completion introduces a new action where the narrator sits on the marble steps and observes people trying to leave, which is not part of the original sequence.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:
- The completion does not include the original's mention of the time of night in a specific way, nor does it reference the "confused and intriguing sounds" coming from the many-windowed room overhanging the terrace before the narrator enters.
- The act of the narrator eluding Jordan’s undergraduate companion, who is engaged in a particular type of conversation with two chorus girls and who invites the narrator to join, is omitted. This step is important for the transition into the next scene.
- The completion lacks the detail about the undergraduate's conversation topic and the narrator's decision to go inside, which provides context for the narrator's movement and the party's atmosphere.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The description of Jordan's movements and posture is inaccurate, as it invents new imagery not found in the original and omits the original's specific sports-related comparison.
- The sequence of events is altered: the completion has the narrator sitting on the steps and observing people trying to leave before hearing sounds from the room, whereas the original has a more direct transition from being left alone to noticing the sounds and entering the room.
- The completion maintains most of the middle and later content accurately, but the early narrative flow and character actions are not in the correct order or are replaced with invented actions.
- There is a minor inaccuracy in the dialogue formatting and attribution in the section with the wives, but this does not significantly affect the overall structure.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“I beg your pardon.”

Gatsby’s voice was almost a whisper, as if he feared the words might shatter the fragile air between them. Daisy, her hand trembling slightly, let her eyes drift from the clock on the mantelpiece to the bouquet of flowers that filled the room with their heavy scent. The rain, which had been falling steadily all afternoon, now tapped gently against the windowpanes, a soft percussion that seemed to underscore the tension in the room.

Nick, standing awkwardly by the door, felt as though he were intruding on a moment too intimate for his presence. He glanced at Gatsby, whose face was pale and earnest, his eyes fixed on Daisy with a longing that was almost painful to witness. Daisy, for her part, seemed caught between laughter and tears, her emotions flickering across her face like sunlight on water.

“I—I’m glad to see you again,” Gatsby said, his voice gaining strength. “It’s been so long. Five years next November, isn’t it?”

Daisy nodded, her lips parted as if she were about to speak, but no words came. Instead, she looked down at her hands, twisting her wedding ring absently. The silence stretched between them, filled only by the ticking of the clock and the distant rumble of thunder.

Nick cleared his throat, trying to dispel the awkwardness. “Would anyone like some tea?” he offered, moving toward the sideboard where a silver tray stood ready. Gatsby started, as if waking from a dream, and nodded gratefully.

“Yes, thank you, Nick,” Daisy said, her voice barely above a whisper. She glanced at Gatsby, her eyes shining with unshed tears. “It’s so strange, seeing you here. I can hardly believe it.”

Gatsby smiled, a shy, almost boyish smile that transformed his face. “I’ve thought of nothing else for years,” he admitted. “Every day, every night. I hoped—” He broke off, his voice faltering.

Daisy reached out, her hand hovering over his for a moment before she drew it back. “I never thought—” she began, but the words caught in her throat. She looked away, blinking rapidly.

Nick busied himself with the tea, pouring it into delicate china cups and handing them around. The ritual seemed to calm Daisy, who took a sip and smiled tremulously at Gatsby.

“Do you remember that afternoon at Louisville?” she asked suddenly. “The one with the white dresses and the music playing?”

Gatsby’s eyes lit up. “Of course I do. I remember everything.”

They fell into reminiscence, their voices growing more animated as they recalled shared memories. The rain outside slowed, then stopped, and a shaft of sunlight broke through the clouds, illuminating the room with a golden glow. For a moment, it seemed as if time itself had turned back, and they were young again, untouched by the years that had passed.

Nick watched them, feeling both hopeful and uneasy. He knew that the past could never truly be recaptured, no matter how fervently one wished for it. Yet, in that moment, with the rain-washed world outside and the fragile hope in Gatsby’s eyes, anything seemed possible.

events.title: Jordan Hints at Secrets; Nick Departs
detailed_summary: While Nick waited for his hat, Jordan and Gatsby emerged from the library.
Gatsby was speaking earnestly to Jordan but quickly became formal as other guests approached to leave.
Jordan's group called for her from the porch, but she paused to shake Nick's hand.
She whispered that she had just heard something astonishing, asking how long they were in the library (about an hour).
Jordan repeated it was 'simply amazing' but stated she was sworn to secrecy, playfully tantalizing Nick.
Yawning, she invited Nick to visit, providing her aunt's name (Mrs. Sigourney Howard) for the phone book.
She hurried away, waving goodbye as she joined her party.
Feeling slightly embarrassed for staying so late on his first visit, Nick joined the remaining guests around Gatsby.
He wanted to explain his earlier search for Gatsby and apologize for not recognizing him.
Gatsby dismissed it warmly, telling Nick not to worry.
He reminded Nick about their hydroplane plans for nine the next morning, his familiar phrase ('old sport') now feeling less personal.
The butler interrupted, informing Gatsby that Philadelphia was on the phone.
Gatsby instructed the butler to tell them he'd be there shortly and bid Nick good night.
As Nick left, Gatsby's smile made him feel a pleasant significance in being among the last guests.
Gatsby repeated 'Good night, old sport... Good night.'

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Good night, old sport… Good night.”

events.text_segment:
As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying some last word to her, but the eagerness in his manner tightened abruptly into formality as several people approached him to say goodbye.
Jordan’s party were calling impatiently to her from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake hands.
“I’ve just heard the most amazing thing,” she whispered. “How long were we in there?”
“Why, about an hour.”
“It was… simply amazing,” she repeated abstractedly. “But I swore I wouldn’t tell it and here I am tantalizing you.” She yawned gracefully in my face. “Please come and see me… Phone book… Under the name of Mrs. Sigourney Howard… My aunt…” She was hurrying off as she talked—her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.
Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.
“Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.” The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And don’t forget we’re going up in the hydroplane tomorrow morning, at nine o’clock.”
Then the butler, behind his shoulder:
“Philadelphia wants you on the phone, sir.”
“All right, in a minute. Tell them I’ll be right there… Good night.”
“Good night.”
“Good night.” He smiled—and suddenly there seemed to be a pleasant significance in having been among the last to go, as if he had desired it all the time. “Good night, old sport… Good night.”

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction:
As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was now talking intently to her in low tones, and when she laughed and held my hand for a moment against her, I knew that I was not the only one he had been talking to that way. Jordan’s party were calling impatiently to her from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake hands.

“I’ve just heard the most amazing thing,” she whispered. “How long were we in there?”

“About an hour.”

“It was—simply amazing. But I swore I wouldn’t tell it and here I am tantalizing you.” She yawned gracefully and into her elegant, bored manner. “If you want to see me any time here’s my aunt’s phone book.” She was hurrying off as she talked—her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.

Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening—and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.

“Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.”

The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And, by the way, I think I’ll take a ride with you on the hydroplane tomorrow morning, if you’ll let me.”

“Just let me know when you’re ready.”

“I’ll be ready about nine o’clock.”

“I’ll be there.”

A butler hurried toward him with the information that Philadelphia was on the wire. He excused himself with a courteous nod and left me standing there with my hat in my hand.

Gatsby’s butler opened the door for me. I thanked him and stepped out into the warm darkness. As I walked down the steps I heard Gatsby’s voice calling, “Good night, old sport... good night.”

“Miss Baker?”

Jordan called to her party, “I’ll be with you in a minute.” Then to me: “If you want to see me any time, here’s my aunt’s name—Mrs. Sigourney Howard. She’s in the phone book.” She hurried off as she spoke. Her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.

Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening—and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.

“Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.”

The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And, by the way, I think I’ll take a ride with you on the hydroplane tomorrow morning, if you’ll let me.”

“Just let me know when you’re ready.”

“I’ll be ready about nine o’clock.”

“I’ll be there.”

A butler hurried toward him with the information that Philadelphia was on the wire. He excused himself with a courteous nod and left me standing there.

I thanked him for the hospitality. As I walked out the door, Gatsby’s formal but friendly smile made me feel as though I was leaving a place of significance. He called after me:

“Good night, old sport... Good night.”

- The closing exchange of goodbyes is condensed and lacks the repetition and nuance present in the original passage.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_2.text:
As I waited for my hat in the hall the door of the library opened and Jordan Baker and Gatsby came out together. He was saying some last word to her, but the eagerness in his manner tightened abruptly into formality as several people approached him to say goodbye. Jordan’s party were calling impatiently to her from the porch, but she lingered for a moment to shake hands.

“I’ve just heard the most amazing thing,” she whispered. “How long were we in there?”

“About an hour.”

“It was—simply amazing. But I swore I wouldn’t tell it and here I am tantalizing you.” She yawned gracefully into her hand. “If you want to see me any time here’s my aunt’s name—Mrs. Sigourney Howard. She’s in the phone book.” She was hurrying off as she talked—her brown hand waved a jaunty salute as she melted into her party at the door.

Rather ashamed that on my first appearance I had stayed so late, I joined the last of Gatsby’s guests, who were clustered around him. I wanted to explain that I’d hunted for him early in the evening—and to apologize for not having known him in the garden.

“Don’t mention it,” he enjoined me eagerly. “Don’t give it another thought, old sport.”

The familiar expression held no more familiarity than the hand which reassuringly brushed my shoulder. “And, by the way, I think I’ll take a ride with you on the hydroplane tomorrow morning.”

At nine o’clock?”

“Yes.”

His tan skin was drawn attractively tight on his face and his short hair looked as though it were trimmed every day. I could see nothing sinister about him. I wondered if the fact that he was not drinking helped to set him off from his guests.

A butler hurried toward him with the information that Philadelphia was on the wire. He excused himself with a courteous nod and they hurried off together. I was looking at an elegant young rough-neck, a year or two over thirty, whose elaborate formality of speech just missed being absurd. Some time before he introduced himself I’d got a strong impression that he was picking his words with care.

Almost at the moment when Mr. Gatsby identified himself, a butler hurried toward him with the information that Philadelphia was on the wire. He excused himself with a courteous nod and they hurried off together. The evening was over. I was one of the few guests who had actually been invited. People were departing in groups, and I lingered for a moment, feeling a pleasant significance in being among the last to leave.

As I walked out the door, Gatsby stood on the steps, smiling at me with that reassuring, understanding smile. “Good night, old sport,” he called. “Good night.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
She was holding something in her hand that I couldn’t see, and she gave it back to Gatsby and walked slowly down the steps. He followed her, his head bent so that I could barely catch a glimpse of his face. They paused at the foot of the stairs and spoke together in low voices for a moment. Then Jordan smiled at me with a bright, artificial expression and said, “We’re leaving, Nick. Are you coming?”

I nodded and followed them out into the warm, starlit night. The party was still in full swing, the laughter and music drifting across the lawns. Gatsby lingered by the door, his eyes searching the crowd as if looking for someone. I wondered what had passed between him and Jordan in the library, but neither of them offered any explanation.

As we walked down the drive, Jordan slipped her arm through mine. “He’s just a man named Gatsby,” she said in a low voice, as if answering my unspoken question. “But he’s got something about him, don’t you think?”

I agreed, though I wasn’t sure what it was. There was a mystery to Gatsby, a sense of hope and longing that seemed to set him apart from the other guests. I glanced back at the house, its windows glowing with light, and wondered what secrets it held.

When we reached the gate, a chauffeur appeared with my hat and coat. I thanked him and turned to say goodnight to Jordan. She smiled again, her eyes glinting in the darkness. “Don’t believe everything you hear about people, Nick,” she said softly. “Gatsby’s all right.”

With that, she slipped away into the night, leaving me alone with my thoughts and the lingering sense of something unfinished.

events.title: Chaos After the Party: The Car Crash
detailed_summary: Walking down the steps, Nick realized the night wasn't over.
Headlights illuminated a chaotic scene near the road: a new coupé, just departed from Gatsby's, rested in a ditch, missing a wheel.
A damaged wall explained the detached wheel, which was being examined by curious chauffeurs.
The chauffeurs' parked cars blocked the road, causing a cacophony of horns from waiting vehicles.
A man in a duster (recognized by Nick as the Owl-Eyed man from the library) stood dazedly in the road, looking between the wreck and the onlookers.
He explained, with astonishment, that the car went into the ditch.
When asked how it happened, he shrugged, claiming ignorance of mechanics.
Pressed further about hitting the wall, he deflected responsibility, stating he knew almost nothing about driving and only knew 'it happened'.
Bystanders criticized him for driving poorly at night.
He indignantly protested that he wasn't even trying to drive.
A hush fell as bystanders reacted with disbelief and concern about his recklessness.
He clarified he wasn't the driver; another man was in the car.
The crowd reacted with a collective gasp as the car door opened slowly.
After a pause, a pale, unsteady individual emerged from the wreck.
Blinking in the headlights and confused by the horns, he swayed before noticing the Owl-Eyed man.
He calmly asked if they had run out of gas.
Multiple people pointed out the missing wheel.
He stared at the wheel, then looked up as if it fell from the sky, admitting he hadn't noticed they stopped.
After a moment, he straightened up and asked determinedly for directions to a gas station.
Several men explained the wheel was detached from the car.
He suggested backing the car out.
When reminded the wheel was off, he hesitated, then concluded there was 'no harm in trying'.
As the horns reached a peak, Nick turned away and walked home across the lawn.
He glanced back once at Gatsby's house, still lit under the moon, appearing fine despite the recent chaos.
A sense of emptiness emanated from the house, highlighting the solitary figure of Gatsby on the porch, raising his hand in a formal farewell gesture.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: A sudden emptiness seemed to flow now from the windows and the great doors, endowing with complete isolation the figure of the host, who stood on the porch, his hand up in a formal gesture of farewell.

events.text_segment:
But as I walked down the steps I saw that the evening was not quite over. Fifty feet from the door a dozen headlights illuminated a bizarre and tumultuous scene. In the ditch beside the road, right side up, but violently shorn of one wheel, rested a new coupé which had left Gatsby’s drive not two minutes before. The sharp jut of a wall accounted for the detachment of the wheel, which was now getting considerable attention from half a dozen curious chauffeurs. However, as they had left their cars blocking the road, a harsh, discordant din from those in the rear had been audible for some time, and added to the already violent confusion of the scene.
A man in a long duster had dismounted from the wreck and now stood in the middle of the road, looking from the car to the tyre and from the tyre to the observers in a pleasant, puzzled way.
“See!” he explained. “It went in the ditch.”
The fact was infinitely astonishing to him, and I recognized first the unusual quality of wonder, and then the man—it was the late patron of Gatsby’s library.
“How’d it happen?”
He shrugged his shoulders.
“I know nothing whatever about mechanics,” he said decisively.
“But how did it happen? Did you run into the wall?”
“Don’t ask me,” said Owl Eyes, washing his hands of the whole matter. “I know very little about driving—next to nothing. It happened, and that’s all I know.”
“Well, if you’re a poor driver you oughtn’t to try driving at night.”
“But I wasn’t even trying,” he explained indignantly, “I wasn’t even trying.”
An awed hush fell upon the bystanders.
“Do you want to commit suicide?”
“You’re lucky it was just a wheel! A bad driver and not even trying!”
“You don’t understand,” explained the criminal. “I wasn’t driving. There’s another man in the car.”
The shock that followed this declaration found voice in a sustained “Ah-h-h!” as the door of the coupé swung slowly open. The crowd—it was now a crowd—stepped back involuntarily, and when the door had opened wide there was a ghostly pause. Then, very gradually, part by part, a pale, dangling individual stepped out of the wreck, pawing tentatively at the ground with a large uncertain dancing shoe.
Blinded by the glare of the headlights and confused by the incessant groaning of the horns, the apparition stood swaying for a moment before he perceived the man in the duster.
“Wha’s matter?” he inquired calmly. “Did we run outa gas?”
“Look!”
Half a dozen fingers pointed at the amputated wheel—he stared at it for a moment, and then looked upward as though he suspected that it had dropped from the sky.
“It came off,” someone explained.
He nodded.
“At first I din’ notice we’d stopped.”
A pause. Then, taking a long breath and straightening his shoulders, he remarked in a determined voice:
“Wonder’ff tell me where there’s a gas’line station?”
At least a dozen men, some of them a little better off than he was, explained to him that wheel and car were no longer joined by any physical bond.
“Back out,” he suggested after a moment. “Put her in reverse.”
“But the wheel’s off!”
He hesitated.
“No harm in trying,” he said.
The caterwauling horns had reached a crescendo and I turned away and cut across the lawn toward home. I glanced back once. A wafer of a moon was shining over Gatsby’s house, making the night fine as before, and surviving the laughter and the sound of his still glowing garden. A sudden emptiness seemed to flow now from the windows and the great doors, endowing with complete isolation the figure of the host, who stood on the porch, his hand up in a formal gesture of farewell.
