LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He seemed to be piecing together the events of the afternoon, his mind working slowly but with a new, grim determination. Michaelis, who had been watching over him, noticed the shift and tried to distract him, but Wilson’s focus was unshakable. He kept repeating, in a low, haunted voice, that he had seen the car before, that it had stopped by his garage, and that he would find out who it belonged to. 

As the afternoon waned, Wilson’s agitation gave way to a cold resolve. He asked Michaelis if he had seen the driver, but Michaelis could only shake his head. Wilson muttered about God seeing everything, his eyes wild and unblinking. He rummaged through his small, cluttered office, searching for something—perhaps a clue, perhaps a weapon. Michaelis grew uneasy, sensing the depth of Wilson’s obsession, but he could do nothing to dissuade him.

Meanwhile, the city outside moved on, oblivious to the tragedy that had unfolded. The newspapers carried the story of Myrtle’s death, but the details were vague, the truth obscured by rumor and speculation. Gatsby, alone in his mansion, waited for a call from Daisy that never came. He wandered through the empty rooms, haunted by memories of their brief, ill-fated reunion. The servants whispered among themselves, uncertain of their future now that Gatsby’s world was unraveling.

Nick Carraway, too, felt the weight of the day’s events. He tried to reach Gatsby, but the phone lines were busy, and when he finally got through, Gatsby’s voice was distant, distracted. Nick urged him to leave town, to escape the consequences that were surely coming, but Gatsby refused. He was still waiting for Daisy, convinced that she would call, that she would choose him over Tom. Nick hung up, feeling helpless and alone.

As evening fell, Wilson emerged from his garage, his face pale and drawn. He carried a small revolver, hidden beneath his coat. He set out on foot, asking questions at every house and business along the way. He described the yellow car, insisting that someone must know who owned it. Most people shook their heads, unwilling to get involved, but a few remembered seeing the car at Gatsby’s parties, or parked outside his mansion.

Word of Wilson’s inquiries spread quickly, and by nightfall, he had made his way to West Egg. The lights of Gatsby’s house shone brightly against the darkness, a beacon for the lost and desperate. Wilson approached the gate, his steps slow but determined. He paused for a moment, looking up at the grand facade, then slipped through the shadows toward the pool where Gatsby was waiting.

Gatsby, unaware of the danger, floated on an air mattress in the pool, lost in thought. He heard footsteps approaching but paid them no mind, assuming it was one of the servants. Wilson emerged from the darkness, his face twisted with grief and rage. Without a word, he raised the revolver and fired. The shots echoed across the water, shattering the stillness of the night.

Gatsby’s body slid gently into the pool, the water closing over him in a silent embrace. Wilson stood for a moment, staring at his handiwork, then turned the gun on himself. The tragedy was complete, the lives of two men ended by a chain of events set in motion by love, jealousy, and the relentless pursuit of a dream.

The next morning, the house was filled with police and reporters, their voices hushed as they pieced together the story. Nick arrived early, his heart heavy with grief. He found Gatsby’s body still in the pool, the water stained with blood. He tried to call Daisy, but she and Tom had already left town, leaving no forwarding address. The servants packed their bags, uncertain of what would happen next.

In the days that followed, Nick struggled to arrange Gatsby’s funeral. Few people came—none of the hundreds who had attended his parties, none of the so-called friends who had basked in his wealth and generosity. Only Owl Eyes, the mysterious figure from the library, appeared, his eyes filled with tears. Together, he and Nick stood by the grave, mourning the man who had dreamed too much and lost everything.

As summer faded into autumn, Nick reflected on the events that had brought them all to this point. He realized that Gatsby’s dream had been doomed from the start, that the world he had tried to create was built on illusions and lies. Yet, for all his faults, Gatsby had possessed a rare and beautiful hope, a belief in the possibility of happiness that set him apart from the cynical, careless people around him.

In the end, Nick decided to return to the Midwest, leaving behind the glittering emptiness of the East. He understood now that the past could never be recaptured, that the green light at the end of Daisy’s dock was just a symbol of all the things they could never have. As he boarded the train, he looked back one last time at Gatsby’s house, its windows dark and silent, and felt a deep sense of loss.

So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

events.title: Wilson's Disappearance, Search, and Gatsby's Final Swim
detailed_summary: By six a.m., Michaelis is exhausted; another man arrives, and they eat breakfast while Wilson is quieter.
Michaelis goes home to sleep.
When Michaelis returns four hours later, Wilson is gone.
Wilson's movements are traced on foot through Port Roosevelt and Gad's Hill, where he bought food he didn't eat.
Witnesses report seeing a man acting strangely.
He disappears for three hours; police assume he was searching garages for the yellow car, based on his statement to Michaelis.
However, no garage attendant confirms seeing him, suggesting he found the information another way.
By half-past two, Wilson is in West Egg asking for directions to Gatsby's house, indicating he now knows Gatsby's name.
Around the same time (two o'clock), Gatsby decides to go for a swim and tells the butler to bring any phone messages to the pool.
He gets the pneumatic mattress from the garage, with the chauffeur helping inflate it.
Gatsby instructs that his main car (the one involved in the accident) not be taken out, despite needing fender repair.
He carries the mattress towards the pool alone, disappearing among the trees.

events.text_segment:
By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. It was one of the watchers of the night before who had promised to come back, so he cooked breakfast for three, which he and the other man ate together. Wilson was quieter now, and Michaelis went home to sleep; when he awoke four hours later and hurried back to the garage, Wilson was gone.
His movements—he was on foot all the time—were afterward traced to Port Roosevelt and then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich that he didn’t eat, and a cup of coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, for he didn’t reach Gad’s Hill until noon. Thus far there was no difficulty in accounting for his time—there were boys who had seen a man “acting sort of crazy,” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road. Then for three hours he disappeared from view. The police, on the strength of what he said to Michaelis, that he “had a way of finding out,” supposed that he spent that time going from garage to garage thereabout, inquiring for a yellow car. On the other hand, no garage man who had seen him ever came forward, and perhaps he had an easier, surer way of finding out what he wanted to know. By half-past two he was in West Egg, where he asked someone the way to Gatsby’s house. So by that time he knew Gatsby’s name.
At two o’clock Gatsby put on his bathing-suit and left word with the butler that if anyone phoned word was to be brought to him at the pool. He stopped at the garage for a pneumatic mattress that had amused his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him to pump it up. Then he gave instructions that the open car wasn’t to be taken out under any circumstances—and this was strange, because the front right fender needed repair.
Gatsby shouldered the mattress and started for the pool. Once he stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and in a moment disappeared among the yellowing trees.

By six o’clock Michaelis was worn out, and grateful for the sound of a car stopping outside. Another man had come to relieve him, and together they sat in the kitchen, eating a silent breakfast while Wilson stared vacantly at the table. When he returned, four hours later, the garage was empty. Wilson had vanished. Later, they traced his movements: on foot through the dust and heat of Port Roosevelt, then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich he never touched. People remembered a man wandering, wild-eyed, muttering to himself, but no one could say where he went for three hours. The police believed he was searching for the yellow car, repeating to anyone who would listen that God saw everything. Yet, no garage man recalled seeing him, and it seemed he had found what he needed by other means.

By half-past two, Wilson appeared in West Egg, asking for directions to Gatsby’s house. He knew the name now. At almost the same moment, Gatsby, restless and alone, decided to swim. He told the butler to bring any phone messages to the pool, and with the chauffeur’s help, dragged the pneumatic mattress from the garage. The main car, its fender still crumpled, was not to be moved, he insisted. Carrying the mattress, Gatsby disappeared among the trees, the sunlight flickering over his white suit as he made his way to the water, leaving the house and its silent telephones behind.

It was one of the watchers of the night before who had promised to come back, so Michaelis cooked breakfast for three; they ate it together, except for Wilson, who sat staring at the table. Then Michaelis went home to sleep.

When he came back four hours later, Wilson was gone. His movements—he was on foot all the time—were afterward traced to Port Roosevelt and then to Gad’s Hill, where he bought a sandwich that he didn’t eat, and a cup of coffee. He must have been tired and walking slowly, for he didn’t reach Gad’s Hill until noon. Some boys who had seen a man “acting sort of crazy” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road remembered seeing him. He disappeared after that for three hours. During that time the police supposed that he was going from garage to garage, asking after a yellow car. On the other hand, no garage man who had seen him ever came forward, and perhaps he had an easier, surer way of finding out what he wanted to know. By half-past two he was in West Egg, asking someone the way to Gatsby’s house. So by that time he knew Gatsby’s name.

At two o’clock Gatsby put on his bathing suit and left word with the butler that if anyone phoned word was to be brought to him at the pool. He stopped at the garage for a pneumatic mattress that had amused his guests during the summer, and the chauffeur helped him to pump it up. Then he gave instructions that the open car wasn’t to be taken out, and not even the front right fender, though it needed repair. And as he left the house he carried the mattress out toward the pool, stopped and shifted it a little, and the chauffeur asked him if he needed help, but he shook his head and carried it on through the yellowing trees.

---

**(End of improved simulated function output.)**

- There is an invented detail where Michaelis is said to leave for his own home around seven o’clock, which is not present in the original and introduces an inaccurate time reference.
- The completion adds invented physical symptoms for Wilson (such as faintness and shivering) that are not described in the original passage.

2. MISSING ELEMENTS:

- The completion does not include the observation that there were boys who saw a man “acting sort of crazy,” and motorists at whom he stared oddly from the side of the road; instead, it replaces these with invented symptoms.
- The completion does not mention the police’s reasoning based on what Wilson said to Michaelis, specifically about having “a way of finding out.”
- The completion omits the detail that the open car’s front right fender needed repair, which is noted as strange in the original.
- The moment when Gatsby disappears among the yellowing trees is missing from the end of the completion.

3. INACCURATE ELEMENTS:
- The completion gives an inaccurate time for Michaelis leaving (around seven o’clock), which is not specified in the original.

- The completion attributes actions and observations (such as the butler and chauffeur watching from the window) that are not present in the original passage.
- The completion omits the detail that Gatsby left word with the butler about phone calls, specifically to be brought word at the pool, which is a subtle but important instruction in the original.

Overall, the completion introduces invented details, omits several key observations and time markers, and alters the sequence of events in places. Greater attention should be paid to preserving the original order of actions, the specific types of observations made by witnesses, and the absence of invented physical symptoms or perspectives.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He left the kitchen and walked out into the yard. A new car had turned into the drive and stopped in front of the house; it was Gatsby’s car, and Gatsby himself was behind the wheel. Michaelis watched as Gatsby stepped out, his face pale and drawn, his eyes searching the shadows as if he expected someone to emerge from the darkness. The air was heavy with the scent of gasoline and the distant hum of the city, but here, in the quiet of the valley, everything seemed suspended, waiting.

Gatsby glanced at Michaelis, who nodded in greeting, though he felt awkward in the presence of this stranger whose name he had only heard whispered in the village. Gatsby hesitated, then walked slowly toward the garage, his footsteps muffled by the dust. He paused at the door, looking in at Wilson, who sat slumped on a bench, his head in his hands. The two men exchanged a brief, silent look—one of shared exhaustion and incomprehension.

Michaelis lingered by the porch, uncertain whether to go back inside or remain where he was. He could hear the low murmur of voices from the garage, punctuated by the occasional clatter of tools or the scrape of a chair. The sun had set, and the first stars were beginning to appear, faint pinpricks of light in the deepening blue. Somewhere in the distance, a train whistle sounded, long and mournful.

After a few minutes, Gatsby emerged from the garage, his expression unreadable. He nodded again to Michaelis, then walked back to his car and sat behind the wheel, staring straight ahead. Michaelis watched him for a moment, then turned and went back into the house, where the lamp still burned on the kitchen table, casting long shadows on the walls.

Inside, Wilson had not moved. He sat motionless, his eyes fixed on the floor, as if trying to make sense of the events that had shattered his world. Michaelis poured himself a cup of coffee, his hands trembling slightly. He felt the weight of the night pressing down on him, the sense that something irrevocable had happened, something that could never be undone. The silence in the house was absolute, broken only by the ticking of the clock and the distant sounds of the city beyond the valley of ashes.

events.title: The Holocaust: Gatsby's Death and Wilson's Suicide
detailed_summary: No phone call comes for Gatsby; the butler waits until four o'clock.
Nick speculates Gatsby no longer expected the call or cared, having perhaps realized his dream was lost and the real world felt alien and grotesque.
He imagines Gatsby perceiving the world as 'material without being real,' filled with 'poor ghosts,' anticipating the 'ashen, fantastic figure' (Wilson) approaching.
The chauffeur hears shots but doesn't initially react.
Nick arrives from the station, his anxious rush up the steps alarming the staff, who Nick believes already suspected the worst.
Nick, the chauffeur, butler, and gardener hurry to the pool.
They find Gatsby's body on the mattress, drifting irregularly in the pool.
A small gust of wind and leaves disturb the mattress's course, tracing a thin red circle in the water from his blood.
As they carry Gatsby's body towards the house, the gardener discovers Wilson's body nearby in the grass.
The murder-suicide is complete.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

events.text_segment:
No telephone message arrived, but the butler went without his sleep and waited for it until four o’clock—until long after there was anyone to give it to if it came. I have an idea that Gatsby himself didn’t believe it would come, and perhaps he no longer cared. If that was true he must have felt that he had lost the old warm world, paid a high price for living too long with a single dream. He must have looked up at an unfamiliar sky through frightening leaves and shivered as he found what a grotesque thing a rose is and how raw the sunlight was upon the scarcely created grass. A new world, material without being real, where poor ghosts, breathing dreams like air, drifted fortuitously about… like that ashen, fantastic figure gliding toward him through the amorphous trees.
The chauffeur—he was one of Wolfshiem’s protégés—heard the shots—afterwards he could only say that he hadn’t thought anything much about them. I drove from the station directly to Gatsby’s house and my rushing anxiously up the front steps was the first thing that alarmed anyone. But they knew then, I firmly believe. With scarcely a word said, four of us, the chauffeur, butler, gardener, and I hurried down to the pool.
There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged its way toward the drain at the other. With little ripples that were hardly the shadows of waves, the laden mattress moved irregularly down the pool. A small gust of wind that scarcely corrugated the surface was enough to disturb its accidental course with its accidental burden. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of transit, a thin red circle in the water.
It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

I drove from the station directly to Gatsby’s house and my rushing anxiously up the front steps was the first news they had of the catastrophe. I crept into the wet shrubbery and peered from the darkness. There was nothing to see. I walked back along the border of the lawn, traversed the gravel softly, and tiptoed up the veranda steps. The house was still and the lawn was empty. I opened the door cautiously and found the butler with a look of hollow-eyed vigilance. Together we went out to the pool.

There was a faint, barely perceptible movement of the water as the fresh flow from one end urged it onward. The touch of a cluster of leaves revolved it slowly, tracing, like the leg of a compass, a thin red circle in the water. It was after we started with Gatsby toward the house that the gardener saw Wilson’s body a little way off in the grass, and the holocaust was complete.

events.title: Investigation, Isolation, and Failed Contact
detailed_summary: The days following Gatsby's death are chaotic, filled with police, media, and onlookers.
A detective labels Wilson a 'madman', setting the tone for inaccurate newspaper reports.
Catherine lies at the inquest, claiming Myrtle was happy with Wilson and never knew Gatsby, effectively simplifying the case to murder-suicide driven by grief.
Catherine's performance convinces the authorities and she portrays herself as deeply mourning her sister.
Nick finds himself aligned with the deceased Gatsby and feels isolated as the sole person truly interested in him.
All inquiries about Gatsby are directed to Nick, solidifying his sense of responsibility.
Nick instinctively calls Daisy shortly after finding Gatsby's body, only to learn she and Tom have left town without a forwarding address or return date.
The Buchanans' departure leaves Nick unable to reach them.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: Can’t say.”

events.text_segment:
After two years I remember the rest of that day, and that night and the next day, only as an endless drill of police and photographers and newspaper men in and out of Gatsby’s front door. A rope stretched across the main gate and a policeman by it kept out the curious, but little boys soon discovered that they could enter through my yard, and there were always a few of them clustered open-mouthed about the pool. Someone with a positive manner, perhaps a detective, used the expression “madman” as he bent over Wilson’s body that afternoon, and the adventitious authority of his voice set the key for the newspaper reports next morning.
Most of those reports were a nightmare—grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. When Michaelis’s testimony at the inquest brought to light Wilson’s suspicions of his wife I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade—but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn’t say a word. She showed a surprising amount of character about it too—looked at the coroner with determined eyes under that corrected brow of hers, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby, that her sister was completely happy with her husband, that her sister had been into no mischief whatever. She convinced herself of it, and cried into her handkerchief, as if the very suggestion was more than she could endure. So Wilson was reduced to a man “deranged by grief” in order that the case might remain in its simplest form. And it rested there.
But all this part of it seemed remote and unessential. I found myself on Gatsby’s side, and alone. From the moment I telephoned news of the catastrophe to West Egg village, every surmise about him, and every practical question, was referred to me. At first I was surprised and confused; then, as he lay in his house and didn’t move or breathe or speak, hour upon hour, it grew upon me that I was responsible, because no one else was interested—interested, I mean, with that intense personal interest to which everyone has some vague right at the end.
I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him, called her instinctively and without hesitation. But she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon, and taken baggage with them.
“Left no address?”
“No.”
“Say when they’d be back?”
“No.”
“Any idea where they are? How I could reach them?”
“I don’t know. Can’t say.”

Most of the reports were a nightmare—grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue. When Michaelis’s testimony at the inquest brought to light Wilson’s suspicions of his wife I thought the whole tale would shortly be served up in racy pasquinade—but Catherine, who might have said anything, didn’t say a word. She showed a surprising amount of character about it too—looked at the coroner with determined eyes under that corrected brow of hers, and swore that her sister had never seen Gatsby, never been in his house, and never, as much as laid a little finger on him. She was completely overcome by the incident, but she held on to her story and the coroner respected her for it.

The most grotesque and fantastic conceits haunted him in his bed at night; a grotesque, circumstantial, eager, and untrue account of the tragedy appeared in the papers. The news spread, and soon a curious crowd gathered on the lawn, peering in at the windows, whispering together, and speculating about the dead man. Some of the servants, with the exception of a few loyal ones, packed up and left, and the house, which had once been filled with music and laughter, now stood silent and deserted.

I found myself responsible, because no one else was interested—interested, I mean, with that intense personal interest to which everyone has some vague right at the end. I called up Daisy half an hour after we found him, called her instinctively and without hesitation. But she and Tom had gone away early that afternoon, and taken baggage with them. No one knew where they had gone, and I was left to deal with Gatsby’s affairs alone.

I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far gone, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. The East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line, I decided to come back home.

events.title: Seeking Support and Facing Indifference
detailed_summary: Nick feels a strong urge to find someone to support Gatsby, even in death, imagining reassuring Gatsby himself.
He tries to contact Meyer Wolfshiem, obtaining his office number after finding he's unlisted, but gets no answer after hours.
Nick feels haunted by Gatsby's imagined plea for help and companionship.
He searches Gatsby's desk for contact information for his parents but finds only Dan Cody's picture.
The next morning, Nick sends the butler to New York with a letter urging Wolfshiem to come.
Neither Wolfshiem nor Daisy contacts Nick as he expected; only more officials arrive.
The butler returns with Wolfshiem's written reply expressing shock but stating he's too busy with important business to get involved.
Wolfshiem asks to be kept informed about the funeral via letter through 'Edgar' and claims ignorance of Gatsby's family.
Nick feels defiant solidarity with Gatsby against the indifferent world.
An unexpected long-distance call comes through, initially thought to be Daisy, but it's a man named Slagle from Chicago.
Slagle, unaware of Gatsby's death, speaks rapidly about 'Young Parke' being arrested in a bond scheme.
Nick interrupts to inform Slagle that Gatsby is dead, leading to silence and an abrupt disconnection.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: I wanted to get somebody for him.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

events.text_segment:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him: “I’ll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don’t worry. Just trust me and I’ll get somebody for you—”
Meyer Wolfshiem’s name wasn’t in the phone book. The butler gave me his office address on Broadway, and I called Information, but by the time I had the number it was long after five, and no one answered the phone.
“Will you ring again?”
“I’ve rung three times.”
“It’s very important.”
“Sorry. I’m afraid no one’s there.”
I went back to the drawing-room and thought for an instant that they were chance visitors, all these official people who suddenly filled it. But, though they drew back the sheet and looked at Gatsby with shocked eyes, his protest continued in my brain:
“Look here, old sport, you’ve got to get somebody for me. You’ve got to try hard. I can’t go through this alone.”
Someone started to ask me questions, but I broke away and going upstairs looked hastily through the unlocked parts of his desk—he’d never told me definitely that his parents were dead. But there was nothing—only the picture of Dan Cody, a token of forgotten violence, staring down from the wall.
Next morning I sent the butler to New York with a letter to Wolfshiem, which asked for information and urged him to come out on the next train. That request seemed superfluous when I wrote it. I was sure he’d start when he saw the newspapers, just as I was sure there’d be a wire from Daisy before noon—but neither a wire nor Mr. Wolfshiem arrived; no one arrived except more police and photographers and newspaper men. When the butler brought back Wolfshiem’s answer I began to have a feeling of defiance, of scornful solidarity between Gatsby and me against them all.
Dear Mr. Carraway. This has been one of the most terrible shocks of my life to me I hardly can believe it that it is true at all. Such a mad act as that man did should make us all think. I cannot come down now as I am tied up in some very important business and cannot get mixed up in this thing now. If there is anything I can do a little later let me know in a letter by Edgar. I hardly know where I am when I hear about a thing like this and am completely knocked down and out.
Yours truly
Meyer Wolfshiem
and then hasty addenda beneath:
Let me know about the funeral etc do not know his family at all.
When the phone rang that afternoon and Long Distance said Chicago was calling I thought this would be Daisy at last. But the connection came through as a man’s voice, very thin and far away.
“This is Slagle speaking…”
“Yes?” The name was unfamiliar.
“Hell of a note, isn’t it? Get my wire?”
“There haven’t been any wires.”
“Young Parke’s in trouble,” he said rapidly. “They picked him up when he handed the bonds over the counter. They got a circular from New York giving ’em the numbers just five minutes before. What d’you know about that, hey? You never can tell in these hick towns—”
“Hello!” I interrupted breathlessly. “Look here—this isn’t Mr. Gatsby. Mr. Gatsby’s dead.”
There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation… then a quick squawk as the connection was broken.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I wanted to get somebody for him. I wanted to go into the room where he lay and reassure him: "I'll get somebody for you, Gatsby. Don't worry. You're not alone." But the house was empty, echoing with the footsteps of servants who had already begun to pack up the remnants of a summer that had ended too soon. The phone sat silent on the table, its promise of connection unfulfilled. I thought of all the people who had crowded his parties, laughing and dancing under the glare of a thousand lights, and I wondered where they were now, when Gatsby needed them most.

I called up Daisy, but there was no answer. I tried Tom, but he had left town, his affairs and his conscience packed away with his luggage. I even thought of Meyer Wolfsheim, the man who claimed to have made Gatsby, but he too was nowhere to be found. Each call I made was met with silence or polite refusal, as if Gatsby's death was an inconvenience, a social obligation they were unwilling to fulfill.

The days passed in a haze of arrangements and disappointment. The undertaker asked me about the funeral, and I realized with a sinking heart that there was no one to invite. Gatsby, who had opened his doors to the world, was to be buried alone. I wrote letters, sent telegrams, but the responses were always the same: regrets, excuses, apologies. No one wanted to be associated with the end of Gatsby's story.

I sat by his body, remembering the man I had come to know. He had believed in the green light, in the promise of the future, in the idea that he could recreate the past. He had built his life around a dream, and when that dream had died, so had he. I thought of the parties, the laughter, the music, and how it had all been a facade, a way to draw Daisy back to him. In the end, it had all been for nothing.

On the day of the funeral, the sky was gray and heavy with rain. Only a handful of people came: myself, the minister, and Gatsby's father, a frail old man who had traveled from the Midwest to see his son one last time. He clutched a photograph of Gatsby as a boy, his eyes filled with pride and sorrow. We stood together by the grave, the rain soaking through our clothes, and said our goodbyes.

After the funeral, I walked through the empty house, the rooms stripped of their finery, the echoes of laughter and music fading into silence. I thought of Gatsby's dream, of the hope that had driven him, and I wondered if it had all been worth it. The world he had tried to enter had rejected him, and the people he had loved had abandoned him. In the end, he had been alone.

As I left West Egg, I looked back at the house one last time. The green light still shone at the end of Daisy's dock, a symbol of the future that Gatsby had never reached. I realized then that we are all chasing something, all reaching for a dream that is just out of reach. And like Gatsby, we are borne back ceaselessly into the past, trying to recapture something that can never be regained.

events.title: Arrival of Gatsby's Father
detailed_summary: On the third day, a telegram arrives from Henry C. Gatz in Minnesota, identifying himself as Gatsby's father and requesting the funeral be postponed until his arrival.
Mr. Gatz arrives, appearing elderly, helpless, and overwhelmed, inappropriately dressed in a heavy coat for the warm weather.
He is visibly emotional, his eyes tearing up, and he nervously pulls at his beard.
Nick takes him inside, offering food and drink, but Mr. Gatz is too distraught to eat or drink steadily.
He explains he learned about his son's death from the Chicago newspaper and came immediately.
Mr. Gatz refers to Wilson as a 'madman'.
Nick leads Mr. Gatz to the drawing-room where Gatsby's body lies and leaves him alone there.
After some time, Mr. Gatz emerges, his initial grief mingling with awe and pride as he takes in the grandeur of Gatsby's house.
Nick helps him upstairs to a bedroom.
Mr. Gatz confirms his name is Gatz, not Gatsby.
He dismisses Nick's suggestion of taking the body West, stating Jimmy (Gatsby) preferred the East where he achieved success.
He proudly speaks of his son's potential, believing he would have been a great man like James J. Hill and contributed significantly to the country.
Overcome with emotion and exhaustion, Mr. Gatz falls asleep almost instantly.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

events.text_segment:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It said only that the sender was leaving immediately and to postpone the funeral until he came.
It was Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day. His eyes leaked continuously with excitement, and when I took the bag and umbrella from his hands he began to pull so incessantly at his sparse grey beard that I had difficulty in getting off his coat. He was on the point of collapse, so I took him into the music-room and made him sit down while I sent for something to eat. But he wouldn’t eat, and the glass of milk spilled from his trembling hand.
“I saw it in the Chicago newspaper,” he said. “It was all in the Chicago newspaper. I started right away.”
“I didn’t know how to reach you.”
His eyes, seeing nothing, moved ceaselessly about the room.
“It was a madman,” he said. “He must have been mad.”
“Wouldn’t you like some coffee?” I urged him.
“I don’t want anything. I’m all right now, Mr.—”
“Carraway.”
“Well, I’m all right now. Where have they got Jimmy?”
I took him into the drawing-room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some little boys had come up on the steps and were looking into the hall; when I told them who had arrived, they went reluctantly away.
After a little while Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth ajar, his face flushed slightly, his eyes leaking isolated and unpunctual tears. He had reached an age where death no longer has the quality of ghastly surprise, and when he looked around him now for the first time and saw the height and splendour of the hall and the great rooms opening out from it into other rooms, his grief began to be mixed with an awed pride. I helped him to a bedroom upstairs; while he took off his coat and vest I told him that all arrangements had been deferred until he came.
“I didn’t know what you’d want, Mr. Gatsby—”
“Gatz is my name.”
“—Mr. Gatz. I thought you might want to take the body West.”
He shook his head.
“Jimmy always liked it better down East. He rose up to his position in the East. Were you a friend of my boy’s, Mr.—?”
“We were close friends.”
“He had a big future before him, you know. He was only a young man, but he had a lot of brain power here.”
He touched his head impressively, and I nodded.
“If he’d of lived, he’d of been a great man. A man like James J. Hill. He’d of helped build up the country.”
“That’s true,” I said, uncomfortably.
He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
I think it was on the third day that a telegram signed Henry C. Gatz arrived from a town in Minnesota. It said only that the sender was leaving immediately and to postpone the funeral until he came. That was my first glimpse of Gatsby’s father. A solemn old man, very helpless and dismayed, bundled up in a long cheap ulster against the warm September day. His eyes leaked continuously with excitement, and, when I took the bag and umbrella from his hands, he began to pull so incessantly at his sparse gray beard that I had difficulty in getting off his coat. He was on the point of collapse, so I took him into the music-room and made him sit down while I sent for something to eat. But he wouldn’t eat, and the glass of milk spilled from his trembling hand.

“I saw it in the Chicago newspaper,” he said. “It was all in the Chicago newspaper. I started right away.”

I tried to think of a way to console him, but he would have none of it. “I’d a little business to attend to,” he said, “but I got here as soon as I could. I know you’re busy, Nick, but I’d like to see my son.”

I took him into the drawing-room, where his son lay, and left him there. Some little boys came up on the steps and peered in at the door; when they saw Mr. Gatz, they fled back down the walk. After a little while Mr. Gatz opened the door and came out, his mouth ajar, his face flushed slightly, his eyes leaking isolated and unpunctual tears. He had reached an age where death no longer has the quality of ghastly surprise, and when he looked around him now for the first time and saw the height and splendor of the hall and the great rooms opening out from it into other rooms, his grief began to be mixed with an awed pride.

“I see you’ve got everything fixed up now,” he said. “I’d a big picture of it all the time.”

He was reluctant to sit down, and kept looking with wild regret at the house, as though he had never seen it before. I suggested that he have some coffee, but he shook his head and the tears continued to flow.

“Have you got a church you go to sometimes, Nick?”

“Not regularly.”

“I’d like to take the body West,” he said. “I’d like to get him back home.”

I thought for a moment he was going to collapse again, but he stood up and looked around the room, his eyes lingering on the details of the house.

“This has been a great success. A great success. He had a lot of brain power here.” He touched his head impressively, and I nodded.

“If he’d of lived, he’d of been a great man. A man like James J. Hill. He’d of helped build up the country.”

“That’s true,” I said, uncomfortably.

He fumbled at the embroidered coverlet, trying to take it from the bed, and lay down stiffly—was instantly asleep.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
It stated that he was coming up to the funeral, and it brought Gatsby’s father, a solemn old man, to the house. He was a helpless man, thin and gray, with a tragic face and trembling hands. He had heard the news by wire and had started at once. He was looking around the house with a kind of awe, as though he had never quite believed in its existence before. There was a quality of wonder in his eyes as he gazed at the high ceilings and the marble steps, the gardens and the fountains, and the great rooms filled with flowers sent by people who cared nothing for the man who had inspired them.

When I met him, he took my hand in a grip that was surprisingly firm. “I’m looking after everything,” I told him. “I’m going to take care of the funeral myself.”

He nodded, his eyes still wandering about the room. “If there’s anything I can do—”

He broke off, and I saw that he was deeply moved. He pulled from his pocket a ragged old photograph, and showed it to me. It was a picture of Gatsby’s house, cracked and faded, as if it had been carried for years. “Jimmy sent me this. I come across it every once in a while, when I’m looking through my things. He had a big future before him, you know. He was always bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something.”

He pulled from his pocket a worn-out book, and showed me the back cover. Inside, written in Gatsby’s boyish hand, was a schedule for self-improvement, a list of resolves and daily tasks. It was the kind of thing a young man might write, full of hope and ambition, and it made me see Gatsby in a new light, as a boy with dreams, not just a man with wealth.

The funeral was a sad affair. Few people came. The minister, myself, Gatsby’s father, and a few servants. Owl Eyes arrived at the last moment, surprised that so few had come. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.” He shook his head, and I saw tears in his eyes.

After the service, Mr. Gatz lingered in the house, wandering from room to room, touching the things his son had owned. He was proud of Gatsby, proud of what he had accomplished, even if he didn’t understand it all. “He made a success,” he said to me. “He was my son, and I’m proud of him.”

As I watched him, I realized that Gatsby’s story was not just about wealth and parties, but about hope, ambition, and the dreams that drive us all. The house, once so full of life, was now empty, but the memory of Gatsby, and the hope he represented, lingered on.

events.title: Klipspringer's Call and Further Disillusionment
detailed_summary: That night, a nervous caller identifies himself as Klipspringer after confirming he's speaking to Nick.
Nick initially feels relieved, hoping for another attendee at Gatsby's funeral.
He informs Klipspringer about the funeral arrangements for the next day.
Klipspringer promises to tell others but sounds hesitant about attending himself.
When pressed, Klipspringer makes excuses about a prior commitment (a picnic) in Greenwich, though he says he'll 'try' to get away.
Nick reacts with disbelief ('Huh!').
Klipspringer reveals the actual reason for his call: to ask if his tennis shoes could be sent to him, as he feels 'helpless' without them.
Disgusted, Nick hangs up before Klipspringer finishes giving his address.
Nick feels ashamed on Gatsby's behalf, reflecting on another acquaintance who implied Gatsby deserved his fate.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.

events.text_segment:
That night an obviously frightened person called up, and demanded to know who I was before he would give his name.
“This is Mr. Carraway,” I said.
“Oh!” He sounded relieved. “This is Klipspringer.”
I was relieved too, for that seemed to promise another friend at Gatsby’s grave. I didn’t want it to be in the papers and draw a sightseeing crowd, so I’d been calling up a few people myself. They were hard to find.
“The funeral’s tomorrow,” I said. “Three o’clock, here at the house. I wish you’d tell anybody who’d be interested.”
“Oh, I will,” he broke out hastily. “Of course I’m not likely to see anybody, but if I do.”
His tone made me suspicious.
“Of course you’ll be there yourself.”
“Well, I’ll certainly try. What I called up about is—”
“Wait a minute,” I interrupted. “How about saying you’ll come?”
“Well, the fact is—the truth of the matter is that I’m staying with some people up here in Greenwich, and they rather expect me to be with them tomorrow. In fact, there’s a sort of picnic or something. Of course I’ll do my best to get away.”
I ejaculated an unrestrained “Huh!” and he must have heard me, for he went on nervously:
“What I called up about was a pair of shoes I left there. I wonder if it’d be too much trouble to have the butler send them on. You see, they’re tennis shoes, and I’m sort of helpless without them. My address is care of B. F.—”
I didn’t hear the rest of the name, because I hung up the receiver.
After that I felt a certain shame for Gatsby—one gentleman to whom I telephoned implied that he had got what he deserved. However, that was my fault, for he was one of those who used to sneer most bitterly at Gatsby on the courage of Gatsby’s liquor, and I should have known better than to call him.

There was a long silence on the other end of the wire, followed by an exclamation... then a quick click as I hung up.

I felt just as if I were talking to another man who had found out that Gatsby had little to live for, and was content to let him go. I couldn’t forgive him or like him, but I saw that what he had done was, to him, entirely justified. It was all very careless and confused. They were careless people, Tom and Daisy—they smashed up things and creatures and then retreated back into their money or their vast carelessness, or whatever it was that kept them together, and let other people clean up the mess they had made...

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
I identified myself, and he muttered something about Gatsby. His voice was hoarse and uncertain, as if he were speaking from a great distance or through a veil of fear. "Is Gatsby there?" he asked abruptly, his tone betraying a sense of urgency. I hesitated, unsure how to respond, for Gatsby was no longer among the living, and the house that had once been filled with laughter and music now stood silent and empty.

"I'm afraid Mr. Gatsby can't come to the phone," I said quietly. There was a pause on the other end, a silence so profound that I could almost hear the man's anxious breathing. "Who is this?" I asked gently, hoping to reassure him.

He hesitated, then finally spoke. "This is Slagle. Meyer told me to call. I—I just wanted to know if everything was all right."

I remembered the name from the list of Gatsby's acquaintances, men who had come and gone through the revolving doors of his parties, their faces blurring together in the haze of champagne and jazz. "I'm sorry to tell you," I said, "but Mr. Gatsby passed away yesterday."

There was a sharp intake of breath, and then a long, heavy silence. "Dead?" he whispered, as if the word itself were too terrible to utter. "How—how did it happen?"

"He was shot," I replied, my voice barely above a whisper. "It was an accident."

The man on the other end of the line muttered something unintelligible, then hung up abruptly, leaving me alone with the echo of his fear and confusion. I sat there for a long time, staring at the silent receiver, feeling the weight of Gatsby's absence settle over the house like a shroud. Outside, the night pressed in against the windows, and the world seemed suddenly colder, emptier, and more uncertain than before.

events.title: Confronting Meyer Wolfshiem
detailed_summary: On the morning of the funeral, Nick goes to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem personally.
He finds Wolfshiem's office, marked 'The Swastika Holding Company'.
Initially, it seems empty, but shouting reveals people behind a partition.
A secretary, Stella, appears and denies Wolfshiem is present, claiming he's in Chicago, despite sounds from within proving otherwise.
Nick insists on seeing Wolfshiem, mentioning Gatsby.
The mention of Gatsby changes Stella's demeanor, and she fetches Wolfshiem.
Wolfshiem greets Nick solemnly, offers a cigar, and reminisces about meeting Gatsby after the war – poor, decorated, but hungry.
He claims credit for Gatsby's success, stating 'I made him' and 'raised him up out of nothing'.
Wolfshiem explains he recognized Gatsby's potential and gentlemanly appearance, using his 'Oggsford' connection.
He boasts of their close association.
Nick asks Wolfshiem to attend the funeral as Gatsby's closest friend.
Wolfshiem expresses a desire to come but ultimately refuses, claiming he cannot get 'mixed up' in a man's death.
He contrasts this with his younger self, who would stick by friends 'to the bitter end'.
Seeing Wolfshiem's determination, Nick prepares to leave.
Wolfshiem advises Nick to show friendship to the living, not the dead, stating his rule is to 'let everything alone' after death.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

events.text_segment:
The morning of the funeral I went up to New York to see Meyer Wolfshiem; I couldn’t seem to reach him any other way. The door that I pushed open, on the advice of an elevator boy, was marked “The Swastika Holding Company,” and at first there didn’t seem to be anyone inside. But when I’d shouted “hello” several times in vain, an argument broke out behind a partition, and presently a lovely Jewess appeared at an interior door and scrutinized me with black hostile eyes.
“Nobody’s in,” she said. “Mr. Wolfshiem’s gone to Chicago.”
The first part of this was obviously untrue, for someone had begun to whistle “The Rosary,” tunelessly, inside.
“Please say that Mr. Carraway wants to see him.”
“I can’t get him back from Chicago, can I?”
At this moment a voice, unmistakably Wolfshiem’s, called “Stella!” from the other side of the door.
“Leave your name on the desk,” she said quickly. “I’ll give it to him when he gets back.”
“But I know he’s there.”
She took a step toward me and began to slide her hands indignantly up and down her hips.
“You young men think you can force your way in here any time,” she scolded. “We’re getting sickantired of it. When I say he’s in Chicago, he’s in Chicago.”
I mentioned Gatsby.
“Oh-h!” She looked at me over again. “Will you just—What was your name?”
She vanished. In a moment Meyer Wolfshiem stood solemnly in the doorway, holding out both hands. He drew me into his office, remarking in a reverent voice that it was a sad time for all of us, and offered me a cigar.
“My memory goes back to when first I met him,” he said. “A young major just out of the army and covered over with medals he got in the war. He was so hard up he had to keep on wearing his uniform because he couldn’t buy some regular clothes. First time I saw him was when he came into Winebrenner’s poolroom at Forty-third Street and asked for a job. He hadn’t eat anything for a couple of days. ‘Come on have some lunch with me,’ I said. He ate more than four dollars’ worth of food in half an hour.”
“Did you start him in business?” I inquired.
“Start him! I made him.”
“Oh.”
“I raised him up out of nothing, right out of the gutter. I saw right away he was a fine-appearing, gentlemanly young man, and when he told me he was at Oggsford I knew I could use him good. I got him to join the American Legion and he used to stand high there. Right off he did some work for a client of mine up to Albany. We were so thick like that in everything”—he held up two bulbous fingers—“always together.”
I wondered if this partnership had included the World’s Series transaction in 1919.
“Now he’s dead,” I said after a moment. “You were his closest friend, so I know you’ll want to come to his funeral this afternoon.”
“I’d like to come.”
“Well, come then.”
The hair in his nostrils quivered slightly, and as he shook his head his eyes filled with tears.
“I can’t do it—I can’t get mixed up in it,” he said.
“There’s nothing to get mixed up in. It’s all over now.”
“When a man gets killed I never like to get mixed up in it in any way. I keep out. When I was a young man it was different—if a friend of mine died, no matter how, I stuck with them to the end. You may think that’s sentimental, but I mean it—to the bitter end.”
I saw that for some reason of his own he was determined not to come, so I stood up.
“Are you a college man?” he inquired suddenly.
For a moment I thought he was going to suggest a “gonnegtion,” but he only nodded and shook my hand.
“Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead,” he suggested. “After that my own rule is to let everything alone.”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
He was sitting in his office, a large, dark room with windows that looked out on the side of a tall building. The walls were lined with bookshelves, but the books were all business directories and ledgers, and the air was heavy with the smell of cigars. When I entered, he looked up from his desk, his small eyes sharp and wary.

"Ah, Mr. Carraway," he said, his accent thick and deliberate. "I was expecting you. Sit down, please."

I sat across from him, feeling the weight of the day pressing down on me. The city outside seemed distant and unreal, as if it belonged to another world.

"I came to see if you would come to Gatsby's funeral," I said quietly.

Wolfshiem's face tightened. He tapped his fingers on the desk, considering. "I'm very sorry for Gatsby, very sorry. But I can't get mixed up in it. There's nothing I can do."

"He was your friend," I insisted. "He helped you when you were starting out."

Wolfshiem nodded, his expression unreadable. "Yes, he was a good man. But now he's gone, and there's nothing to be done. I have my own life, my own business."

I felt a surge of anger. "He had no one else. No family, no friends."

Wolfshiem looked away, his eyes fixed on the window. "Let us learn to show our friendship for a man when he is alive and not after he is dead," he said. "After that, my office is closed."

I stood up, feeling defeated. "Thank you for your time," I said, and left the office.

The city seemed even more alien as I walked back to the train station. The people on the streets moved with purpose, their faces set and indifferent. No one knew or cared about Gatsby, or about the tragedy that had unfolded in West Egg.

When I returned to the house, I found it empty and silent. The rooms were filled with the ghosts of parties and laughter, but now there was only stillness. I called Daisy, but she had gone away, leaving no forwarding address. I tried to reach out to others, but no one wanted to be involved.

The day of the funeral was gray and overcast. The rain fell steadily, soaking the ground and turning the cemetery into a field of mud. Only a handful of people attended: myself, the minister, a few servants, and Gatsby's father, who had arrived from Minnesota the day before. He was a thin, stooped man, his face lined with grief and confusion.

We stood together by the grave as the minister spoke the final words. The rain drummed on the coffin, and the wind whipped the flowers from our hands. There was no music, no eulogy, no sign of the life that had once filled Gatsby's house with light and laughter.

After the service, Gatsby's father showed me a photograph he carried in his wallet. It was a picture of Gatsby's house, taken from the lawn. "He was proud of this place," he said softly. "He worked hard for it."

I nodded, unable to find the words to comfort him. The emptiness of the moment was overwhelming.

As we left the cemetery, I looked back at the grave, the earth already closing over Gatsby's dreams. The world had moved on, indifferent to his hopes and ambitions. I realized then that Gatsby had been chasing an illusion, a vision of the past that could never be recaptured.

In the days that followed, I packed up my things and prepared to return to the Midwest. The city no longer held any appeal for me. The parties, the glamour, the promise of something more—they were all gone, leaving only memories and regrets.

On my last night in West Egg, I walked down to the shore and looked out across the bay. The green light still burned at the end of Daisy's dock, a symbol of all that Gatsby had desired and lost. I thought of his faith, his hope, his relentless pursuit of a dream that had always been just out of reach.

As I turned to leave, I understood at last the truth of Gatsby's story. He had believed in the possibility of a new beginning, in the power of love to redeem the past. But in the end, he had been destroyed by the very dream that had sustained him.

And so we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past.

events.title: Mr. Gatz's Pride and Gatsby's Boyhood Ambitions
detailed_summary: Nick returns to West Egg amidst darkening skies and drizzle.
He finds Mr. Gatz pacing excitedly, his pride in Gatsby and his possessions growing.
Mr. Gatz eagerly shows Nick a worn photograph of Gatsby's house that Jimmy had sent him, pointing out details.
He recounts Gatsby visiting two years prior and buying him the house he currently lives in.
Mr. Gatz reflects that Gatsby's running away from home was justified by his ambition for a 'big future'.
He emphasizes Gatsby's generosity after achieving success.
Mr. Gatz then reveals an old, ragged copy of 'Hopalong Cassidy' belonging to Gatsby as a boy.
He shows Nick the back flyleaf containing a detailed daily schedule dated September 12, 1906.
The schedule includes time for exercise, study (electricity, elocution, inventions), work, and sports.
Beneath the schedule are 'General Resolves': avoiding wasted time, quitting smoking/chewing, bathing regularly, reading improving material, saving money, and being better to parents.
Mr. Gatz sees the book and its contents as proof of Jimmy's inherent drive to 'get ahead' and improve himself.
He proudly reads the items aloud, expecting Nick to be deeply impressed.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

events.text_segment:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing and now he had something to show me.
“Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”
It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.
“Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”
“Very well. Had you seen him lately?”
“He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”
He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.
“Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”
He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last flyleaf was printed the word schedule, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:
Rise from bed	6:00	a.m.
Dumbell exercise and wall-scaling	6:15⁠–⁠6:30	“
Study electricity, etc.	7:15⁠–⁠8:15	“
Work	8:30⁠–⁠4:30	p.m.
Baseball and sports	4:30⁠–⁠5:00	“
Practise elocution, poise and how to attain it	5:00⁠–⁠6:00	“
Study needed inventions	7:00⁠–⁠9:00	“
General Resolves
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
No more smokeing or chewing.
Bath every other day
Read one improving book or magazine per week
Save $5.00 [crossed out] $3.00 per week
Be better to parents
“I came across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”
“It just shows you.”
“Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”
He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

simple_agent_extraction_refined_1.text:
When I left his office the sky had turned dark and I got back to West Egg in a drizzle. After changing my clothes I went next door and found Mr. Gatz walking up and down excitedly in the hall. His pride in his son and in his son’s possessions was continually increasing, and now he had something to show me.

“Jimmy sent me this picture.” He took out his wallet with trembling fingers. “Look there.”

It was a photograph of the house, cracked in the corners and dirty with many hands. He pointed out every detail to me eagerly. “Look there!” and then sought admiration from my eyes. He had shown it so often that I think it was more real to him now than the house itself.

“Jimmy sent it to me. I think it’s a very pretty picture. It shows up well.”

“Very well. Had you seen him lately?”

“He come out to see me two years ago and bought me the house I live in now. Of course we was broke up when he run off from home, but I see now there was a reason for it. He knew he had a big future in front of him. And ever since he made a success he was very generous with me.”

He seemed reluctant to put away the picture, held it for another minute, lingeringly, before my eyes. Then he returned the wallet and pulled from his pocket a ragged old copy of a book called Hopalong Cassidy.

“Look here, this is a book he had when he was a boy. It just shows you.”

He opened it at the back cover and turned it around for me to see. On the last fly-leaf was printed the word SCHEDULE, and the date September 12, 1906. And underneath:

Rise from bed....................6.00 A.M.
Dumbbell exercise and wall-scaling........6.15-6.30
Study electricity, etc...............7.15-8.15
Work..........................8.30-4.30 P.M.
Baseball and sports.................4.30-5.00
Practice elocution, poise and how to attain it....5.00-6.00
Study needed inventions.............7.00-9.00

GENERAL RESOLVES
No wasting time at Shafters or [a name, indecipherable]
No more smoking or chewing
Bath every other day
Read one improving book or magazine per week
Save $5.00 {crossed out} $3.00 per week
Be better to parents

“I come across this book by accident,” said the old man. “It just shows you, don’t it?”

“It just shows you.”

“Jimmy was bound to get ahead. He always had some resolves like this or something. Do you notice what he’s got about improving his mind? He was always great for that. He told me I et like a hog once, and I beat him for it.”

He was reluctant to close the book, reading each item aloud and then looking eagerly at me. I think he rather expected me to copy down the list for my own use.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
The lights of Gatsby’s house, usually blazing with the promise of festivity, were dimmed, and the long drive was empty except for the faint glimmer of a lantern at the far end. As I walked up the path, the wet gravel crunching beneath my shoes, I felt the weight of the evening settle over me—a heaviness that seemed to press down from the low, clouded sky. The rain had deepened the colors of the lawns and hedges, and the air was thick with the scent of wet earth and the distant, briny tang of the Sound.

I paused at the marble steps, glancing up at the great house. Its windows, usually aglow with laughter and music, now reflected only the shifting shadows of the storm. Somewhere inside, I imagined Gatsby moving restlessly from room to room, his silhouette flickering behind the drawn curtains, waiting for a signal that would not come. The sense of anticipation that had once electrified the air was gone, replaced by a silence that seemed to echo with the memory of vanished parties and lost hopes.

I let myself in quietly, the echo of my footsteps swallowed by the thick carpets. The hall was deserted, the only sound the distant ticking of a clock. I thought of the people who had once crowded these rooms, their voices rising in a chorus of gaiety, and of Gatsby himself, standing apart yet always watching, always hoping. Now, the house felt like a stage after the final curtain, the actors gone and the audience dispersed, leaving only the ghostly traces of their presence.

I made my way to the library, where the soft glow of a single lamp illuminated the rows of unread books. I sat for a moment, listening to the rain tapping against the windows, and tried to collect my thoughts. The events of the day—the confrontation in the city, the drive back through the gathering storm, the terrible accident—swirled in my mind, refusing to settle into any kind of order. I felt as if I were caught in a dream from which I could not wake, a dream in which the boundaries between past and present, hope and despair, had become hopelessly blurred.

After a while, I rose and went to the window. The drizzle had become a steady rain, and the lights of the neighboring houses were blurred halos in the mist. Somewhere across the bay, I knew, Daisy was sitting in her own house, her life untouched by the tragedy that had unfolded. I wondered if she was thinking of Gatsby, or if she had already turned the page, leaving him behind like a chapter in a book she no longer wished to read.

I stood there for a long time, watching the rain fall, and felt the emptiness of the great house press in around me. It was as if the world itself had grown smaller, diminished by the loss of a single, impossible dream.

events.title: The Sparse Funeral
detailed_summary: Shortly before 3 PM, the Lutheran minister arrives for the funeral.
Nick and Mr. Gatz anxiously watch for other mourners, but none arrive.
As time passes, Mr. Gatz becomes increasingly worried, commenting nervously about the rain.
The minister checks his watch repeatedly; Nick persuades him to wait half an hour longer, but it's futile.
Around 5 PM, a small procession of three vehicles (hearse, limousine with Nick, Gatz, and minister, and station wagon with servants and postman) reaches the cemetery in heavy drizzle.
As they enter the cemetery, Nick hears a car stop and sees someone approaching.
It is the 'owl-eyed man' Nick previously met in Gatsby's library.
Owl Eyes, soaked by the rain, wipes his glasses to watch the burial.
Nick momentarily tries to think of Gatsby but finds him distant, only recalling Daisy's silence.
Someone murmurs a blessing for the dead in the rain, and Owl Eyes says 'Amen'.
After the brief ceremony, the attendees quickly return to the cars.
Owl Eyes speaks to Nick at the gate, expressing surprise that no one else came, remarking how hundreds used to attend Gatsby's parties.
He wipes his glasses again and calls Gatsby 'The poor son-of-a-bitch'.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

events.text_segment:
A little before three the Lutheran minister arrived from Flushing, and I began to look involuntarily out the windows for other cars. So did Gatsby’s father. And as the time passed and the servants came in and stood waiting in the hall, his eyes began to blink anxiously, and he spoke of the rain in a worried, uncertain way. The minister glanced several times at his watch, so I took him aside and asked him to wait for half an hour. But it wasn’t any use. Nobody came.
About five o’clock our procession of three cars reached the cemetery and stopped in a thick drizzle beside the gate—first a motor hearse, horribly black and wet, then Mr. Gatz and the minister and me in the limousine, and a little later four or five servants and the postman from West Egg, in Gatsby’s station wagon, all wet to the skin. As we started through the gate into the cemetery I heard a car stop and then the sound of someone splashing after us over the soggy ground. I looked around. It was the man with owl-eyed glasses whom I had found marvelling over Gatsby’s books in the library one night three months before.
I’d never seen him since then. I don’t know how he knew about the funeral, or even his name. The rain poured down his thick glasses, and he took them off and wiped them to see the protecting canvas unrolled from Gatsby’s grave.
I tried to think about Gatsby then for a moment, but he was already too far away, and I could only remember, without resentment, that Daisy hadn’t sent a message or a flower. Dimly I heard someone murmur “Blessed are the dead that the rain falls on,” and then the owl-eyed man said “Amen to that,” in a brave voice.
We straggled down quickly through the rain to the cars. Owl-eyes spoke to me by the gate.
“I couldn’t get to the house,” he remarked.
“Neither could anybody else.”
“Go on!” He started. “Why, my God! they used to go there by the hundreds.”
He took off his glasses and wiped them again, outside and in.
“The poor son-of-a-bitch,” he said.

events.title: Reflections on East vs. West and Decision to Leave
detailed_summary: Nick recalls vivid memories of returning home to the Midwest from school during Christmas.
He describes the atmosphere at Chicago's Union Station, the goodbyes, and the train journey into the snowy landscape.
He reflects on the feeling of connection to his homeland experienced during those trips.
Nick defines his Midwest not by landscapes but by these youthful returns and the cozy familiarity of home.
He realizes the story he's told is fundamentally about Westerners (himself, Gatsby, Tom, Daisy, Jordan) who were ill-suited to Eastern life.
Even at its most exciting, Nick found the East possessed a 'quality of distortion'.
He envisions West Egg as a grotesque night scene, comparing it to an El Greco painting, symbolizing moral decay and indifference.
After Gatsby's death, the East feels irredeemably haunted and distorted to Nick.
As autumn sets in, he decides to leave the East and return home to the Midwest.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time.
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.

events.text_segment:
One of my most vivid memories is of coming back West from prep school and later from college at Christmas time. Those who went farther than Chicago would gather in the old dim Union Station at six o’clock of a December evening, with a few Chicago friends, already caught up into their own holiday gaieties, to bid them a hasty goodbye. I remember the fur coats of the girls returning from Miss This-or-That’s and the chatter of frozen breath and the hands waving overhead as we caught sight of old acquaintances, and the matchings of invitations: “Are you going to the Ordways’? the Herseys’? the Schultzes’?” and the long green tickets clasped tight in our gloved hands. And last the murky yellow cars of the Chicago, Milwaukee and St. Paul railroad looking cheerful as Christmas itself on the tracks beside the gate.
When we pulled out into the winter night and the real snow, our snow, began to stretch out beside us and twinkle against the windows, and the dim lights of small Wisconsin stations moved by, a sharp wild brace came suddenly into the air. We drew in deep breaths of it as we walked back from dinner through the cold vestibules, unutterably aware of our identity with this country for one strange hour, before we melted indistinguishably into it again.
That’s my Middle West—not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow. I am part of that, a little solemn with the feel of those long winters, a little complacent from growing up in the Carraway house in a city where dwellings are still called through decades by a family’s name. I see now that this has been a story of the West, after all—Tom and Gatsby, Daisy and Jordan and I, were all Westerners, and perhaps we possessed some deficiency in common which made us subtly unadaptable to Eastern life.
Even when the East excited me most, even when I was most keenly aware of its superiority to the bored, sprawling, swollen towns beyond the Ohio, with their interminable inquisitions which spared only the children and the very old—even then it had always for me a quality of distortion. West Egg, especially, still figures in my more fantastic dreams. I see it as a night scene by El Greco: a hundred houses, at once conventional and grotesque, crouching under a sullen, overhanging sky and a lustreless moon. In the foreground four solemn men in dress suits are walking along the sidewalk with a stretcher on which lies a drunken woman in a white evening dress. Her hand, which dangles over the side, sparkles cold with jewels. Gravely the men turn in at a house—the wrong house. But no one knows the woman’s name, and no one cares.
After Gatsby’s death the East was haunted for me like that, distorted beyond my eyes’ power of correction. So when the blue smoke of brittle leaves was in the air and the wind blew the wet laundry stiff on the line I decided to come back home.
